text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse: [These are] the analogues of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel [e.g., Torah is compared to a good woman; idolatry, to an adulteress.]
text.0_Chapter, 1_Verse: [He stated these analogues] to make known [(to men the importance of studying Torah, which is)] wisdom and mussar (reproof), to make understood words of understanding.
text.0_Chapter, 2_Verse: To take [from them (the analogues)] wise instruction: charity, justice [(in accordance with the truth)], and justness [(compromise)].
text.0_Chapter, 3_Verse: To give to the innocent, wisdom; to the youth, [(who has not yet learned anything)], knowledge and counsel.
text.0_Chapter, 4_Verse: The wise one will hear [these analogues] and he will add to his learning, and the understanding one [(who understands one thing from another)] will [(in addition to what he hears)] acquire stratagems.
text.0_Chapter, 5_Verse: [They will take heart] to understand [both] the analogue and [even] the figure [e.g., (2:16) Beware of idolatry (the analogue); Beware of the strange woman (the figure)], the words of the wise [(the Torah expositors)] and their allusions.
text.0_Chapter, 6_Verse: [(The book proper begins now.)] The fear of the L-rd is the first [i.e., the tithe] of knowledge [("Put your fear before your knowledge")], for fools [(those who do not fear the L-rd)] spurn wisdom and mussar.
text.0_Chapter, 7_Verse: Hear, my son, the mussar of your Father [(what the L-rd gave to Moses, written and oral)], and do not forsake the Torah of your mother [(the congregation of Israel)] [("the Torah of your mother" - the words of the scribes, what they originated and added, making safeguards for the Torah)].
text.0_Chapter, 8_Verse: For they are a chaplet of grace to your head and a necklace to your throat.
text.0_Chapter, 9_Verse: My son, if sinners entice you, do not yield.
text.0_Chapter, 10_Verse: If they say: Come with us; let us lie in wait for blood. Let us lurk for the innocent one [to spill his blood] — without cause —
text.0_Chapter, 11_Verse: Let us swallow them [(the innocent)] up alive, like Sheol [(which swallows the body entire)], and whole [i.e., at the height of their prosperity], as those who descend to the pit [i.e., let us kill them and inherit their wealth],
text.0_Chapter, 12_Verse: All precious wealth is found [with them]; we will fill up our houses with spoil,
text.0_Chapter, 13_Verse: Cast your lot among us; let there be one pouch for all of us —
text.0_Chapter, 14_Verse: My son, do not walk in the way with them; keep your feet from their path.
text.0_Chapter, 15_Verse: For their feet run to [their own] evil, and they [heedlessly] hasten to spill blood.
text.0_Chapter, 16_Verse: For [though] the net is spread [(with food morsels)] for naught [i.e., for no apparent reason] in the eyes of all winged creatures,
text.0_Chapter, 17_Verse: They [(the hunters)] are lying in wait for their blood and lurking for their lives.
text.0_Chapter, 18_Verse: So, [(as with the birds)] are the ways of all committers of theft [(The "morsels" are tempting to them, and easily attainable, but, in the end,)] it [the theft] takes the life of its owner [i.e., the thief].
text.0_Chapter, 19_Verse: The wisdom [of Torah] sings in the thoroughfare [i.e., in the house of study]; in the expanses [i.e., in the places where Torah is "expanded upon,"] it lifts its voice.
text.0_Chapter, 20_Verse: In the fore of [its] din, it calls out, at the entrances of the gates [(where the elders sit)]. It spreads its words throughout the city, [saying:]
text.0_Chapter, 21_Verse: How long, O simpletons, will you love deception, and scoffers lust mockery, and fools hate wisdom?
text.0_Chapter, 22_Verse: Return to my reproof. Do I not speak my spirit to you and make known my words to you?
text.0_Chapter, 23_Verse: [(But)] because I have called and you have refused; because I have stretched forth my arm [(to signal you to turn to me)], and you have not listened,
text.0_Chapter, 24_Verse: And you have voided all of my counsel [(whose purpose was to exalt you in the world)], and did not desire my reproof,
text.0_Chapter, 25_Verse: I, likewise, will laugh at your misfortune and make mock when your fear arrives.
text.0_Chapter, 26_Verse: When your fear comes as a [sudden] cloud, and your misfortune, as a whirlwind; when affliction and oppression come upon you,
text.0_Chapter, 27_Verse: Then they will call me, and I will not answer; they will search for me, but they will not find me.
text.0_Chapter, 28_Verse: Because they hated wisdom and did not choose to fear the L-rd.
text.0_Chapter, 29_Verse: They did not desire my counsel; they spurned all of my reproof.
text.0_Chapter, 30_Verse: They will eat the fruits of their ways and will be sated with their counsels [(by afflictions in this world; and the principal will be guarded for them in Gehinnom)].
text.0_Chapter, 31_Verse: For the waywardness of the simpletons will slay them, and the smugness of the fools [(in seeing the prosperity of the wicked and following in their footsteps)] will cause them to go lost.
text.0_Chapter, 32_Verse: But he who listens to me will rest secure [in this world], and in quiet [(in the world to come)] from the fright of evil [(the judgment of Gehinnom)].
text.1_Chapter, 0_Verse: [The L-rd says: I will deem you] My son if you take My words [to heart] and store up My mitzvoth with you.
text.1_Chapter, 1_Verse: [My words are] that your ears listen to wisdom [Torah] and incline your heart to understanding.
text.1_Chapter, 2_Verse: When you call out to understanding, when you put forth your voice for understanding —
text.1_Chapter, 3_Verse: If you seek for it as silver, if you search for it as hidden treasure —
text.1_Chapter, 4_Verse: Then you will understand the fear of the L-rd and find the knowledge of G-d.
text.1_Chapter, 5_Verse: [(And this, indeed, warrants the effort of acquisition)] for the L-rd [Himself] gives wisdom; from His mouth is knowledge and understanding.
text.1_Chapter, 6_Verse: He hid Torah for the just [(He secreted it with Himself for twenty-six generations until He gave it to the generation of the desert.)] It is a shield for those who walk in innocence,
text.1_Chapter, 7_Verse: [to teach them] to observe the paths of justice; and He will guard the way of His saints [(that they not stumble)].
text.1_Chapter, 8_Verse: Then you will understand charity, justice, and justness [viz. 1:3] — every good path.
text.1_Chapter, 9_Verse: When wisdom enters your heart, and knowledge is pleasant to your soul,
text.1_Chapter, 10_Verse: Then Torah will watch over you; understanding will guard you.
text.1_Chapter, 11_Verse: To save you from the way of evil, from the man who speaks contraries.
text.1_Chapter, 12_Verse: From those who forsake just paths to walk in ways of darkness.
text.1_Chapter, 13_Verse: Who are happy in the doing of evil, who rejoice in evil contrariness,
text.1_Chapter, 14_Verse: Whose ways are crooked and who are crooked in their ways —
text.1_Chapter, 15_Verse: To save you from the strange woman [(idolatry)], from the foreign woman, who smooths over her words.
text.1_Chapter, 16_Verse: Who forsakes the master [(the husband)] of her youth and forgets the covenant of her G-d.
text.1_Chapter, 17_Verse: [(reversion to 2:16)] for her house descends [i.e., causes you to descend] to death, and her paths, to the shades [(and Torah will guard you from this fall)].
text.1_Chapter, 18_Verse: All who come to her will not return, and will not attain the paths of life.
text.1_Chapter, 19_Verse: [(reversion to 2:12)] So that you walk in the way of the good and heed the path of the righteous.
text.1_Chapter, 20_Verse: For the just will dwell in the land [(in the world to come)], and the innocent will remain in it [(when the wicked descend to Gehinnom)].
text.1_Chapter, 21_Verse: And the wicked will be cut off from the land, and the faithless uprooted from it.
text.2_Chapter, 0_Verse: My son, do not forget my Torah, and let your heart guard my mitzvoth.
text.2_Chapter, 1_Verse: For length of days and years of life, and peace will they bequeath to you.
text.2_Chapter, 2_Verse: Let lovingkindness and truth not forsake you. Entwine them around your throat; inscribe them on the tablet of your heart.
text.2_Chapter, 3_Verse: And you will find favor and [(be regarded as possessing)] goodly wisdom in the eyes of G-d and man.
text.2_Chapter, 4_Verse: Trust to the L-rd with all your heart [(and spend liberally to find a teacher to learn from)], and do not rely upon your own understanding.
text.2_Chapter, 5_Verse: In all of your ways know Him, and He will straighten your paths.
text.2_Chapter, 6_Verse: Do not be wise in your own eyes [(to spurn the reproof of your chastisers)]; fear the L-rd and depart from evil.
text.2_Chapter, 7_Verse: For it [wisdom] is healing to your navel and marrow to your bones.
text.2_Chapter, 8_Verse: Honor the L-rd from [all] that He has bequeathed to you [(even a pleasing voice)], and from the first of all your produce.
text.2_Chapter, 9_Verse: And your silos will be filled to satiety, and your vats will burst forth with wine.
text.2_Chapter, 10_Verse: The afflictions of the L-rd, my son, do not despise, and do not reject His chastisement.
text.2_Chapter, 11_Verse: For whom the L-rd loves, He chastises, and [(afterwards He conciliates him)] as a father conciliates [his] son.
text.2_Chapter, 12_Verse: Happy is the man who has found wisdom and the man who [is so conversant with it that he] "spouts" understanding.
text.2_Chapter, 13_Verse: For better is its commerce [i.e., its interchange] than the commerce of silver [(for in the latter instance, one takes one commodity, and the other, another; but in the instance of wisdom, both [(ideas)] remain with each)], and its produce is better than fine gold.
text.2_Chapter, 14_Verse: It is more precious than pearls, and all of your desires do not equal it [(in worth)].
text.2_Chapter, 15_Verse: There is length of days [(and, it goes without saying, wealth and honor)] in its right hand [i.e., to those who pursue it for its own sake]; wealth and honor [(but not length of days)] in its left hand [i.e., to those who do not pursue it for its own sake].
text.2_Chapter, 16_Verse: Its ways are ways of pleasantness and all of its paths are peace.
text.2_Chapter, 17_Verse: It is a tree of life to those who hold fast to it, and those who bolster it are fortunate.
text.2_Chapter, 18_Verse: The L-rd with wisdom [Torah] founded the earth; He established the heavens with understanding [Torah].
text.2_Chapter, 19_Verse: Through its [Torah's] knowledge, the depths were cleaved, and the heavens dripped dew.
text.2_Chapter, 20_Verse: [Therefore, the entire world having been created through Torah,] do not let it depart from your eyes. Heed [it in] act and thought.
text.2_Chapter, 21_Verse: And they [(the Torah's wisdom, knowledge, etc.)] will be life to your soul and grace to your throat.
text.2_Chapter, 22_Verse: Then you will walk your way securely and your foot will not stumble.
text.2_Chapter, 23_Verse: When you lie down, you will not fear, and when you recline, your sleep will be pleasant.
text.2_Chapter, 24_Verse: [For] you will not fear a sudden fright or the destruction of the wicked when it comes.
text.2_Chapter, 25_Verse: For the L-rd will be with you in your trust, and He will guard your feet from entrapment.
text.2_Chapter, 26_Verse: Do not withhold good from its owners [(i.e., if your neighbor wants to help the poor, do not stop him)] if you have the power to do [so].
text.2_Chapter, 27_Verse: [And] do not tell your [poor] friend: "Go, and return, and tomorrow I will give [it to you]," if you have it [now].
text.2_Chapter, 28_Verse: Do not plot evil against your friend. Does he not dwell trustingly with you?
text.2_Chapter, 29_Verse: Do not [bring a] quarrel [i.e., a complaint] upon a man in vain, if he has not done you evil [(it being written [Leviticus 19:18]: "And you shall love your fellow as yourself.")]
text.2_Chapter, 30_Verse: Do not envy the man of violence [(to do as he does if you see him prospering)], and do not choose any of his ways.
text.2_Chapter, 31_Verse: For the abomination of the L-rd is the crooked one, and His counsel is with the just.
text.2_Chapter, 32_Verse: The blight of the L-rd is in the house of the wicked, and He blesses the abode of the righteous.
text.2_Chapter, 33_Verse: If one follows scoffers, he [himself] will scoff with them, and if [he follows] the humble, he will give [i.e., project] favor [i.e., his deeds will find favor in the eyes of men].
text.2_Chapter, 34_Verse: The wise inherit honor and the fools reap shame [for themselves].
text.3_Chapter, 0_Verse: Hear, children, the Father's mussar, and listen to know understanding.
text.3_Chapter, 1_Verse: "For I [(says the prophet, speaking in the name of the L-rd)] have given you a goodly acquisition; do not forsake My Torah."
text.3_Chapter, 2_Verse: For I was a son to my Father [viz. II Samuel 7:14], a tender and only (child) before my mother [i.e., select and beloved by my people].
text.3_Chapter, 3_Verse: And He taught me and He said to me: My words will sustain your heart; heed My mitzvoth and live.
text.3_Chapter, 4_Verse: Acquire wisdom; acquire understanding. Do not forget and do not stray from the words of My mouth.
text.3_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not forsake it [Torah], and it will guard you; love it, and it will protect you.
text.3_Chapter, 6_Verse: The first of [your] wisdom [is to] acquire wisdom [from your teacher], and [afterwards,] in all of your acquisitions, acquire understanding [(of one thing from another)].
text.3_Chapter, 7_Verse: Search it [(wisdom)] out and it will uplift you; it will honor you when you embrace it.
text.3_Chapter, 8_Verse: It will set upon your head a chaplet of grace; it will bestow a crown of glory upon you.
text.3_Chapter, 9_Verse: Hear my son and take My words, and they will add years of life unto you.
text.3_Chapter, 10_Verse: I have instructed you in the way of wisdom; I have led you in just paths.
text.3_Chapter, 11_Verse: When you walk, your steps will not be constricted [(so that you will not fall)], and when you run, you will not stumble.
text.3_Chapter, 12_Verse: Hold fast to mussar [(Torah)]; do not let it go. Guard it, for it is your life.
text.3_Chapter, 13_Verse: Do not come to the path of the wicked, and do not tread in the way of the evildoers.
text.3_Chapter, 14_Verse: Shun it; do not cross it. Veer away from it and pass on.
text.3_Chapter, 15_Verse: For they [(those who walk upon it)] do not sleep if they do no evil; their sleep is stolen if they cause no stumbling.
text.3_Chapter, 16_Verse: For they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
text.3_Chapter, 17_Verse: But the path of the righteous is as the shining light [of day], growing in brightness until the day is fast [i.e., until mid-day].
text.3_Chapter, 18_Verse: But the way of the wicked is as pitch darkness; they know not what they stumble on.
text.3_Chapter, 19_Verse: My son, listen to My words; incline your ear to My exhortations.
text.3_Chapter, 20_Verse: Let them not depart from your eyes; guard them within your heart.
text.3_Chapter, 21_Verse: For they are life to him who finds them, and healing to all his flesh.
text.3_Chapter, 22_Verse: From every guarding [(From everything of which the Torah said: "Guard yourself")], guard your heart [(whether it be a slight or a severe transgression)], for from it [(i.e., even from the seemingly slight one)] are the issues [(reward and punishment, respectively,)] of life.
text.3_Chapter, 23_Verse: Remove from yourself crooking of the mouth [(of others in derision of your deeds)]; and widening of the lips [in condemnation of you] keep far from you.
text.3_Chapter, 24_Verse: Let your eyes look before you [(for the straight and the true)], and your lids will straighten [the path] before you.
text.3_Chapter, 25_Verse: Weigh the path of your feet [(the loss of a mitzvah against its reward; the "reward" of a transgression against its omission)], and all of your ways will be [correctly] established.
text.3_Chapter, 26_Verse: Do not turn right or left [(from the just weight)]; remove your feet from evil.
text.4_Chapter, 0_Verse: My son, be attentive to my wisdom; give ear to my understanding,
text.4_Chapter, 1_Verse: To heed thoughts — and your lips will guard wisdom.
text.4_Chapter, 2_Verse: For the lips of the strange woman [(heresy)] drip as a honeycomb, and her palate is smoother than oil.
text.4_Chapter, 3_Verse: But her end is bitter as wormwood, as sharp as a two-edged sword.
text.4_Chapter, 4_Verse: Her footpaths lead to death; her steps approach Sheol.
text.4_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not weigh the path of life [(i.e., which path to take) by the standards of "the strange woman," for] her paths terminate [in Sheol, and] you will not know [(to take heed until you have fallen there)].
text.4_Chapter, 6_Verse: And now, [my] sons, listen to me, and do not depart from the words of my mouth.
text.4_Chapter, 7_Verse: Remove your ways far from her, and do not come close to the doors of her house.
text.4_Chapter, 8_Verse: Lest you give your glory to others, [i.e., lest you turn your heart to other gods)], and your [remaining] years to the cruel one [(the prince of Gehinnom)].
text.4_Chapter, 9_Verse: Lest strangers [(the prophets of the ba'al)] be sated with your strength [(the money they extort from you by their falsehoods)], and [the products of] your toil [be found] in the house of a strange [god].
text.4_Chapter, 10_Verse: And you will make moan in your latter end, when your flesh and form fall away.
text.4_Chapter, 11_Verse: And you will say: "How could I have hated mussar and my heart spurned rebuke?"
text.4_Chapter, 12_Verse: "And [how could] I not have listened to the voice of my masters and not inclined my ear to my teachers?"
text.4_Chapter, 13_Verse: "There is but a step between me and all evil [(Gehinnom)] in the midst of congregation and assembly."
text.4_Chapter, 14_Verse: Drink [(gathered)] water from your pit [(the Torah of Moses)], and [(in consequence,)] flowing water from your well, [and, in consequence of that)],
text.4_Chapter, 15_Verse: Your springs will spread outwards [i.e., you will acquire many disciples]. In the thoroughfares [of the city] the streams of [your] waters will spread.
text.4_Chapter, 16_Verse: They [(the waters)] will be yours alone, strangers not sharing them with you [(as opposed to 5:10), and, in consequence],
text.4_Chapter, 17_Verse: Your source will be blessed and you will rejoice in the wife of your youth [(i.e., in the Torah that you learned from your youth)].
text.4_Chapter, 18_Verse: [She will be to you] a beloved hind, of excellent favor; her breasts will sate you at all times; in their love, you will stray always [(from your other affairs, and she will guard them for you)].
text.4_Chapter, 19_Verse: Why, then, my son, should you stray with a strange woman and embrace the lap of a woman who is foreign to you?
text.4_Chapter, 20_Verse: For before the eyes of the L-rd are the ways of a man, and He weighs all of his paths [(for transgression or merit)].
text.4_Chapter, 21_Verse: The transgressions of the wicked one will entrap him, and he will be hoisted in the cords of his sin.
text.4_Chapter, 22_Verse: He will die for refusal of chastisement, and for the abundance of his foolishness in which he has strayed.
text.5_Chapter, 0_Verse: My son, if you have gone security for your friend; if you have put forth your hand [in pledge] for a stranger,
text.5_Chapter, 1_Verse: [Or if] you have been trapped by the words of your mouth, you have been ensnared by the words of your mouth.
text.5_Chapter, 2_Verse: Do this, then, my son, and be saved; for you have fallen into your friend's hand. Go and free [your] palm [i.e., pay him his money]; and [(if you owe him no money, but "have been trapped by the words of your mouth," to speak harshly against him,)] then multiply your friends [i.e., send many friends to him to ask him to forgive you].
text.5_Chapter, 3_Verse: Give no sleep to your eyes or slumber to your lids.
text.5_Chapter, 4_Verse: Rescue yourself [from there] as the deer from the hand [of the hunter], and as the bird from the [fowler's] snare.
text.5_Chapter, 5_Verse: Go to the ant, you sluggard; see its ways and grow wise.
text.5_Chapter, 6_Verse: Though there is no officer, or guard, or ruler over her [to spur her on or to keep one ant from stealing from the other],
text.5_Chapter, 7_Verse: Still, she prepares her [own] food in the summer and stores up her [own] food in the harvest time.
text.5_Chapter, 8_Verse: How long will you recline, O sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?
text.5_Chapter, 9_Verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to recline,
text.5_Chapter, 10_Verse: And your poverty [(in Torah)] will arrive as an unexpected guest, and your want as a shielded warrior [to defend his master].
text.5_Chapter, 11_Verse: The faithless man is a man of wrong, walking with contorted mouth [(in slanderous intent)].
text.5_Chapter, 12_Verse: He winks with his eyes, "speaks" with his feet, points with his fingers.
text.5_Chapter, 13_Verse: There are contraries in his heart. He plots evil all the time and stirs up strife [(between man and his Creator)].
text.5_Chapter, 14_Verse: Therefore, his undoing will come with suddenness; he will be broken in an instant, not to be healed.
text.5_Chapter, 15_Verse: These six are hated by the L-rd, and the seventh is the abomination of His soul:
text.5_Chapter, 16_Verse: Haughty eyes, a false tongue, and hands spilling innocent blood,
text.5_Chapter, 17_Verse: A heart plotting vain thoughts, feet hastening to run to evil,
text.5_Chapter, 18_Verse: A false witness spouting lies, and the inciter of strife among brothers.
text.5_Chapter, 19_Verse: Heed, my son, the command of your father, and do not forsake the instruction of your mother.
text.5_Chapter, 20_Verse: Tie them to your heart; entwine them around your throat.
text.5_Chapter, 21_Verse: In your going [i.e., in your life], it shall guide you. In your lying down [(in the grave)], it shall guard you. And when you awake [(at the resurrection)], it will speak for you [(i.e., in your behalf)].
text.5_Chapter, 22_Verse: For a mitzvah is a lamp [(which illumines for a given time)], and Torah is light [(which illumines forever)], and the chastisements of mussar are [(what impel a man to)] the road of life.
text.5_Chapter, 23_Verse: To guard you from an evil woman [(idolatry)], from the sealing [of your eyes] by the foreign woman's tongue.
text.5_Chapter, 24_Verse: Do not lust her beauty in your heart, and let her not take you [i.e., your wisdom] with [the winking of] her lids.
text.5_Chapter, 25_Verse: For [lust] for a harlot [reduces one] to [begging for] a loaf of bread, and the adulterous woman ensnares the precious soul.
text.5_Chapter, 26_Verse: Will a man draw forth fire into his lap and his clothes not be burned?
text.5_Chapter, 27_Verse: Will a man walk on coals and his feet not be scorched?
text.5_Chapter, 28_Verse: So, he who comes to his friend's wife; no one who touches her will go clean.
text.5_Chapter, 29_Verse: The thief is not despised when he steals to fill his soul; for he is hungry.
text.5_Chapter, 30_Verse: And, [in addition,] when he is found, he can [make indemnification (to the point of)] paying sevenfold [i.e., a great sum], [and, if necessary,] he will give all the wealth of his house.
text.5_Chapter, 31_Verse: But one who commits adultery, lacks a heart; the destroyer of his soul — he will do it [(the act)].
text.5_Chapter, 32_Verse: Plague and shame will he find [(Idolatry and adultery are visited with plague)], and his shame will not be wiped out.
text.5_Chapter, 33_Verse: For the wrath of the Strong One is aroused against him, and He will not be merciful on the day of revenge.
text.5_Chapter, 34_Verse: He will not accept any ransom [(to atone for his idolatry)]; and He will refuse though you raise the bribe.
text.6_Chapter, 0_Verse: My son, heed My words, and store up My mitzvoth with you.
text.6_Chapter, 1_Verse: Heed my mitzvoth and live, and My Torah as the pupil of your eye.
text.6_Chapter, 2_Verse: Tie them on your fingers; inscribe them on the tablet of your heart.
text.6_Chapter, 3_Verse: Say to wisdom: "You are my sister," and call understanding your kin.
text.6_Chapter, 4_Verse: To guard you from a strange woman, from the foreign woman who smooths over her words.
text.6_Chapter, 5_Verse: For from the window of my house, through my lattice, I looked out.
text.6_Chapter, 6_Verse: And I saw among the simple, I discerned among the boys, a youth void of understanding.
text.6_Chapter, 7_Verse: Passing in the market-place near her corner, walking by her house.
text.6_Chapter, 8_Verse: In the darkness, in the eve of day, in the heart of night and pitch darkness.
text.6_Chapter, 9_Verse: And, behold, a woman came before him, in the nakedness of a harlot and her heart besieged [(by lewdness)].
text.6_Chapter, 10_Verse: Moaning [in enticement] and straying [(from the path)], her feet not frequenting her house.
text.6_Chapter, 11_Verse: Sometimes in the courtyard, sometimes in the streets — she lurks at every corner.
text.6_Chapter, 12_Verse: And she seized him and kissed him; she thrust forth her face and said to him:
text.6_Chapter, 13_Verse: I have prepared a great feast, [for] today I have paid my vows [i.e., I have sacrificed my vow-offerings and my peace-offerings.]
text.6_Chapter, 14_Verse: That is why I have gone out to you, to look for you and to find you.
text.6_Chapter, 15_Verse: I have decked my bed with spreads, braided with Egyptian yarns.
text.6_Chapter, 16_Verse: I have scented my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
text.6_Chapter, 17_Verse: Come, let us sate ourselves with love until the morning; let us rejoice in love-making.
text.6_Chapter, 18_Verse: For the Man is not at home [(You see that G-d has removed His shechinah and has given all of His good to the idolators.)]
text.6_Chapter, 19_Verse: He has taken the money-pouch with him [i.e., He has killed the best of them]; He will [not] come home until the appointed time.
text.6_Chapter, 20_Verse: She has led him astray with her store of sophistication; she has felled him with the smoothness of her lips.
text.6_Chapter, 21_Verse: Suddenly, he goes after her; as an ox to the slaughter he comes, as [a snake spewing] venom [speeding] to the chastisement of a fool.
text.6_Chapter, 22_Verse: — Until [her] arrow splits his liver. [He is] as a bird racing to the trap, not knowing that it will cost him his life.
text.6_Chapter, 23_Verse: And now, [my] sons, listen to me, and heed the words of my mouth.
text.6_Chapter, 24_Verse: Do not incline your heart to her ways; do not stray in her paths.
text.6_Chapter, 25_Verse: For she has taken many lives; the number of her victims is legion.
text.6_Chapter, 26_Verse: Her house is the road to Sheol, descending to the chambers of death.
text.7_Chapter, 0_Verse: Does wisdom [(Torah)] not call out [(what follows [verse 4, etc.])] and [does] understanding not give forth its voice?
text.7_Chapter, 1_Verse: Atop the heights, overlooking the many-pathed way, it stands.
text.7_Chapter, 2_Verse: Near the gateways, atop the dome [(of the gate, where people sit)], the doored entry-way, it shouts:
text.7_Chapter, 3_Verse: To you, men, do I call, and I lift my voice to the sons of men.
text.7_Chapter, 4_Verse: Simpletons, understand wisdom, and fools, make your hearts understand.
text.7_Chapter, 5_Verse: Give ear, for I will speak noble thoughts, and my mouth will open to just words.
text.7_Chapter, 6_Verse: For my palate will utter truth, and evil is abominated by my lips.
text.7_Chapter, 7_Verse: All the words of my mouth are spoken in righteousness; they contain no twisting or perversion.
text.7_Chapter, 8_Verse: They are all correct to him who understands, and just to the finders of wisdom.
text.7_Chapter, 9_Verse: Take my mussar rather than silver, and knowledge rather than choice fine gold.
text.7_Chapter, 10_Verse: For wisdom is better than pearls, and all one's desires cannot compare to it [in worth].
text.7_Chapter, 11_Verse: I [Torah] am wisdom. I dwell [near] subtlety [(One who has learned Torah is subtle in all matters)]. I provide knowledge for thoughts [(to combat the evil inclination)].
text.7_Chapter, 12_Verse: [(the "mussar" [verse 4]):] The fear of the L-rd is hatred of evil — pride and haughtiness, the path of evil, and a mouth that speaks opposites [of what one thinks]. I hate [all of these].
text.7_Chapter, 13_Verse: With me there is counsel [against the evil inclination] and weakening [of it]. I [give] understanding; with me is strength.
text.7_Chapter, 14_Verse: Through me, kings will rule [(for I teach them the laws and the judgments)], and princes will legislate righteously.
text.7_Chapter, 15_Verse: Through me, regents will hold sway, and the lordliest of all those who judge in righteousness.
text.7_Chapter, 16_Verse: I [(the L-rd)] love its [(Torah's)] lovers, and My probers [i.e., those who probe Me through Torah] shall find Me.
text.7_Chapter, 17_Verse: Wealth and honor are with me [(Torah)]; great fortune, given freely.
text.7_Chapter, 18_Verse: My fruits are better than gold and fine gold, and my produce is choicer than silver.
text.7_Chapter, 19_Verse: I lead [men] in the way of righteousness, in the midst of the paths of justice.
text.7_Chapter, 20_Verse: I have much to bequeath to my lovers, and I shall fill their stores.
text.7_Chapter, 21_Verse: The L-rd acquired me [(Torah)] (as) the beginning of His way [i.e., before the creation of the universe)], before His deeds of yore.
text.7_Chapter, 22_Verse: I was enthroned from the beginning. I am among the first, [(Seven things, Torah among them, preceded the creation of the world)], [among] the precursors of the earth.
text.7_Chapter, 23_Verse: When there were yet no depths, I was formed; when there were no pools rich with water.
text.7_Chapter, 24_Verse: Before the mountains were sunk [(into the waters)]; before the hills, was I formed.
text.7_Chapter, 25_Verse: Before there had been made the land [(Eretz Yisrael)] and its environs [(the other lands)], and the head of the dust of the world [(Adam)].
text.7_Chapter, 26_Verse: When He prepared the heavens, there was I; when He etched out the globe [of the earth] upon the face of the deep [(as an impassable bound)].
text.7_Chapter, 27_Verse: When He strengthened the heavens above; when He fortified the basins of the depths.
text.7_Chapter, 28_Verse: When He set His statute to the sea [(at the creation, that it split in the time of Moses)], when He etched out the foundations of the earth.
text.7_Chapter, 29_Verse: I was then His nursling, [His] delight, day [by] day [(two thousand years [the L-rd's "day" being a thousand years] — Torah being created two thousand years before the creation of the universe)], playing before Him at all times.
text.7_Chapter, 30_Verse: Laughing at the world, His earth, [("laughing" at all the generations of the wicked, from Adam until Noach, and from Noach until Abraham)] and [finding] my delight with the sons of man [(the generations of the desert, which accepted the Torah)].
text.7_Chapter, 31_Verse: And now, children, listen to me — and fortunate are they who heed my ways.
text.7_Chapter, 32_Verse: Hear mussar, and grow wise, and do not reject [my mussar].
text.7_Chapter, 33_Verse: Fortunate is the man who gives ear to me, to guard my doors each day [(to enter the house of study and the house of prayer first and to leave last)], to guard my doorposts.
text.7_Chapter, 34_Verse: For he who finds me finds life and elicits favor from the L-rd.
text.7_Chapter, 35_Verse: But he who sins against me despoils his soul; all who hate me love death.
text.8_Chapter, 0_Verse: Wisdom has built her house [i.e., the L-rd has built the world with wisdom]. She has carved out its seven pillars [(the seven days of creation)].
text.8_Chapter, 1_Verse: She has slaughtered her slaughtering and diluted her wine and also set her table [(with all the creations, wet and dry)].
text.8_Chapter, 2_Verse: She has sent out to call [to] her young ones [Adam and Eve] on the wings of the city heights:
text.8_Chapter, 3_Verse: "Who is a simpleton? Let him turn in here" [and gain wisdom]. [And so] will she say to him who is void of understanding.
text.8_Chapter, 4_Verse: "Come and eat of my bread, and drink of the wine that I have poured."
text.8_Chapter, 5_Verse: "Leave [your paths], simpletons, and live, and walk in the way of understanding."
text.8_Chapter, 6_Verse: [(an exhortation against reproving inciters to idolatry:)] ([But] he who chastises the scoffer brings shame upon himself; and he who reproves the wicked one [brings upon himself] his blemish [i.e., the wicked one shames him and shuns him].)
text.8_Chapter, 7_Verse: Do not chastise the scoffer, lest he hate you. Chastise the wise man, and he will love you.
text.8_Chapter, 8_Verse: Give [words of wisdom] to the wise one [(an apt disciple)] and he will become even wiser. Make known [wisdom] to the righteous one, and he will add to his acquisitions [(by his own reasoning)].
text.8_Chapter, 9_Verse: The beginning of wisdom is fear of the L-rd, and the knowledge of the holy ones is [the essence of] understanding.
text.8_Chapter, 10_Verse: For through me [(wisdom)] your days will increase, and they [(these days)] will add for you years of life [i.e., years of sustenance and wealth].
text.8_Chapter, 11_Verse: If you have become wise, you have become wise for your own good, and if you have been a scoffer, you alone will bear [your punishment].
text.8_Chapter, 12_Verse: The foolish woman moans foolishly, not knowing why.
text.8_Chapter, 13_Verse: She sits at the door of her house, [(to scout out the passers-by)], [and] upon a chair atop the city heights
text.8_Chapter, 14_Verse: to call out to the passers-by, who walk a just path.
text.8_Chapter, 15_Verse: (Whoever is a simpleton, let him turn in here, and [whoever is] void of understanding). And thus will she say to him:
text.8_Chapter, 16_Verse: "Stolen waters are sweet, and bread eaten secretly, more pleasing" [i.e., cohabitation with a married woman is more pleasurable than that with an unmarried one.]
text.8_Chapter, 17_Verse: And they [the passers-by] do not know that the shades are there, that those [who heed] her call [descend] to the depths of Sheol.
text.9_Chapter, 0_Verse: The analogues of Solomon: The wise son rejoices his Father, and the foolish one [e.g., Yeravam ben Nevat] is the sorrow of his mother [(the congregation of Israel)].
text.9_Chapter, 1_Verse: Treasures of wickedness will not avail, but charity rescues from death. [(And if you would ask: Whence is he who is profuse in his charity to derive sustenance?)]
text.9_Chapter, 2_Verse: The L-rd will not cause the soul of the righteous one to hunger, and the destructiveness of the wicked will cast [them] down.
text.9_Chapter, 3_Verse: The poor man makes a deceitful scale [(One who is poor in Torah renders false decisions)], and the hand of the diligent [(one who diligently seeks out the truth)] prospers [(in his judgments)].
text.9_Chapter, 4_Verse: The wise son gathers in [his grain] in the summer, but the shameful one sleeps in harvest time.
text.9_Chapter, 5_Verse: Blessings [will descend] upon the head of the righteous one, but [their] violence will smother the mouth of the wicked [and kill them].
text.9_Chapter, 6_Verse: Remembrance [i.e., mention] of the righteous one will be [accompanied by] a blessing, but the name of the wicked one will rot [(from lack of mention)].
text.9_Chapter, 7_Verse: The wise of heart will take hold of mitzvoth [(e.g., (Exodus 13:19), While Israel busied themselves with the plunder of Egypt, Moses busied himself with taking the bones of Joseph for burial)], but the fool will weary his lips [(with talking, and do nothing)].
text.9_Chapter, 8_Verse: He who walks in innocence will walk securely, but he who perverts his ways will be broken.
text.9_Chapter, 9_Verse: He who winks his eye [(inciting to evil)] produces grief [(when the wink is acted upon)], but the fool wearies [his purpose] with his lips.
text.9_Chapter, 10_Verse: A well of life is the mouth of the righteous one, but the mouth of the wicked conceals [their intended] violence.
text.9_Chapter, 11_Verse: [Present] hatred awakens [long-forgotten] quarrels, but love conceals all offense.
text.9_Chapter, 12_Verse: In the lips of the understanding one there will be found wisdom [e.g., David admitted "I have sinned," when reproved by Nathan (II Samuel 12:14)], but [only] a rod [will suffice] for the back of the one void of understanding.
text.9_Chapter, 13_Verse: The wise conceal wisdom [(in their heart, to guard it)], but the mouth of the fool [brings] destruction near.
text.9_Chapter, 14_Verse: The wealth of the rich one [(in Torah)] is the city of his strength, but the breaking of the poor is their poverty [(in Torah)].
text.9_Chapter, 15_Verse: The act of the righteous one is a source of life, but the produce of the wicked one is [a source of] shortening [of life].
text.9_Chapter, 16_Verse: The heeding of mussar is a path to life, but he who abandons chastisement causes [himself and others] to stray.
text.9_Chapter, 17_Verse: The concealer of hatred [in his heart] has lying [(flattering)] lips, and he who utters slander is a fool.
text.9_Chapter, 18_Verse: With an abundance of words, offense will not cease, and he who spares his lips is wise.
text.9_Chapter, 19_Verse: Choice silver is the tongue [i.e., the reproof] of the righteous one, but the understanding of the wicked is minute [(and they pay no heed to his reproof)].
text.9_Chapter, 20_Verse: The lips of the righteous one [(in prayer)] will feed many, but the fools, void of understanding [(and paying him no heed)], will die.
text.9_Chapter, 21_Verse: The blessing of the L-rd, by itself, enriches, and [requires] no further toil along with it.
text.9_Chapter, 22_Verse: As play to the fool is acting upon evil counsel, as [acting upon] wisdom is [play] to the man of understanding.
text.9_Chapter, 23_Verse: The fear of the wicked one will come upon him [e.g., (Genesis 11:4 and 8)], and He will fulfill the desire of the righteous.
text.9_Chapter, 24_Verse: When the tempest passes, the wicked one is no more, but the righteous one is the foundation of the world.
text.9_Chapter, 25_Verse: As vinegar to the teeth and as smoke to the eyes, so is the sluggard to his senders.
text.9_Chapter, 26_Verse: The fear of the L-rd will increase days, but the years of the wicked shall be shortened.
text.9_Chapter, 27_Verse: The hope of the righteous [will culminate in] joy, but the hope of the wicked will go lost.
text.9_Chapter, 28_Verse: The way of the L-rd is a stronghold to the innocent, and [(their not pursuing it)], a breaking to the workers of iniquity.
text.9_Chapter, 29_Verse: The righteous one will not stoop forever, [(but ultimately will rise)], and the wicked shall not endure in the land.
text.9_Chapter, 30_Verse: The mouth of the righteous one will utter wisdom, but the tongue of contraries will be cut off.
text.9_Chapter, 31_Verse: The lips of the righteous one know [how to] conciliate [G-d and man], but the mouth of the wicked [speaks] contraries.
text.10_Chapter, 0_Verse: Deceitful scales are the abomination of the L-rd, and a whole weight is His will.
text.10_Chapter, 1_Verse: When willfulness comes there comes shame, and with the humble [there comes] wisdom.
text.10_Chapter, 2_Verse: The innocence of the just shall lead them, and the perversion of the faithless shall despoil them.
text.10_Chapter, 3_Verse: Wealth will not avail in the day of wrath, but charity will rescue from death.
text.10_Chapter, 4_Verse: The righteousness of the innocent one straightens his path, and the wicked one will fall in his [own] wickedness.
text.10_Chapter, 5_Verse: The righteousness of the just shall rescue them, and the faithless will be trapped in the destruction [they have plotted].
text.10_Chapter, 6_Verse: When a wicked man dies, the hope [of his hangers-on] is lost, and the hope of his sons perishes [(his merit not "standing" for them, [as opposed to the lot of the sons of the righteous])].
text.10_Chapter, 7_Verse: The righteous one is rescued from affliction [("when the wicked man dies")], and the wicked one comes in his place.
text.10_Chapter, 8_Verse: With [his] mouth, the flatterer destroys [his friend], but with knowledge [of the Torah, which exhorts against succumbing to the flatterer's enticements (viz. Deuteronomy 13:9)], the righteous are rescued.
text.10_Chapter, 9_Verse: The city exults in the good of the righteous, and when the wicked perish there is rejoicing.
text.10_Chapter, 10_Verse: By the blessing of the just the ceiling is sustained [(When the kings of Judah were just, the "ceiling" of the Temple was kept from falling by their prayers)], but by the mouth of the wicked it is razed.
text.10_Chapter, 11_Verse: He who shames his friend lacks a heart, and the man of understanding will remain silent [(when he is thus shamed, viz. I Samuel 10:27)].
text.10_Chapter, 12_Verse: He who reveals a secret is a tale-bearer, and the faithful of spirit conceals a thing.
text.10_Chapter, 13_Verse: When [(in a time of affliction)], there are no stratagems [(e.g., taking stock of one's acts, fasting, repentance, etc)], the people shall fall, and there is salvation in much counsel.
text.10_Chapter, 14_Verse: One will be utterly broken for having gone security for a stranger, and the hater of hand-shaking [(in pledge)] shall be secure.
text.10_Chapter, 15_Verse: The woman of favor [(the congregation of Israel)] courts honor [(the honor of the L-rd and His Torah)], and tyrants court wealth.
text.10_Chapter, 16_Verse: One who is kind to his kin is a saintly man, and the cruel man [is he who] vexes his kin.
text.10_Chapter, 17_Verse: The deed of the wicked one betrays him [(i.e., it does not fulfill his intent)], but one who sows charity — [it (the charity) is] a true weir [i.e., it "traps" what is intended as a weir traps fish].
text.10_Chapter, 18_Verse: The truth [i.e., the end result] of charity is life, and one who pursues evil [does so] for his death.
text.10_Chapter, 19_Verse: The abomination of the L-rd are the perverse of heart, and those who walk in innocence are His desire.
text.10_Chapter, 20_Verse: [Punishment will come from G-d's] hand to [the] hand [of the sinner]. He will not be cleansed [i.e., absolved] of the evil [he has done]; but the righteous [(sometimes do)] escape [(in the merit of their fathers)].
text.10_Chapter, 21_Verse: As a golden ring [(which becomes besmirched)] in the snout of a pig, so is a beautiful woman [(a Torah scholar)] departing from wisdom [(Torah)].
text.10_Chapter, 22_Verse: The desire of the righteous is good alone; the hope [i.e., the expectation] of the wicked is wrath [(Gehinnom)].
text.10_Chapter, 23_Verse: There is scattering [of one's wealth (in charity)] with even more increase, and holding back from just [(giving)] for want alone.
text.10_Chapter, 24_Verse: The magnanimous soul will [itself] grow fat, and the sater [of the poor] will himself be sated [with good].
text.10_Chapter, 25_Verse: He who withholds produce [(Torah teaching)] will be cursed by the nations, but blessing [will descend] upon the head of the provider.
text.10_Chapter, 26_Verse: He who desires good [(for others and chastises them to that end)] seeks conciliation [i.e., that the L-rd be reconciled to them], but he who seeks out evil [for them] — it will come to him.
text.10_Chapter, 27_Verse: He who trusts in his wealth shall fall, but the righteous shall sprout as leaves.
text.10_Chapter, 28_Verse: He who inherits the wind [i.e., the lazy man, who neither studies Torah nor works] vexes his household [(leaving them without sustenance)], and [this] fool will [ultimately] become a servant to the wise of heart.
text.10_Chapter, 29_Verse: The fruits of [the deeds of] the righteous one are a tree of life [for the world], and he who takes [i.e., acquires] souls [(whom he teaches the way of good [viz. Genesis 12:5])] is wise.
text.10_Chapter, 30_Verse: If the righteous one is paid [i.e., punished for his evil deeds] upon this earth, how much more so [will retribution come (in this world or the next) to] the wicked one (who persists in) sinning.
text.11_Chapter, 0_Verse: He who loves chastisement loves wisdom, but he who hates rebuke is a boor.
text.11_Chapter, 1_Verse: The good man draws forth favor from the L-rd [(for the world)], but the scheming one [draws forth] evil.
text.11_Chapter, 2_Verse: A man will not establish himself with wickedness, but the root of the righteous will not founder.
text.11_Chapter, 3_Verse: A woman of valor is her husband's crown, but a shameful one is like rot in his bones.
text.11_Chapter, 4_Verse: The thoughts of the righteous are [to do] justice; the stratagems of the wicked are [to work] deceit.
text.11_Chapter, 5_Verse: The words of the wicked are a siege upon blood [i.e., they seek to kill], but the mouth of the just will rescue them [(their intended victims)].
text.11_Chapter, 6_Verse: When the wicked are overthrown, they are no more, but the house of the righteous will stand.
text.11_Chapter, 7_Verse: According to a man's wisdom [(whether great or small)] will he be praised [i.e., will he receive his reward], but the perverse of heart will be put to shame.
text.11_Chapter, 8_Verse: Better one who esteems himself lightly and is a servant unto himself, than one who holds himself honored and lacks bread [(not condescending to serve himself!)]
text.11_Chapter, 9_Verse: The righteous one knows the needs of his beast, but the mercies of the wicked are cruel.
text.11_Chapter, 10_Verse: He who works his earth will be sated with bread, but he who pursues vanities is lacking a heart.
text.11_Chapter, 11_Verse: The wicked one desires the hunting of the evil ones [i.e., what thieves wrest from their victims], but the root of the righteous will give [(its own fruit)].
text.11_Chapter, 12_Verse: By the sin of the lips [(of the generation of the flood, who said [Job 21:15]: "What is G-d that we should serve Him?")], an evil snare [(the flood, consumed them)], but the righteous one [(Noah)] escaped calamity.
text.11_Chapter, 13_Verse: From the fruits of a man's mouth, he will be sated with good [i.e., As reward for their discourse, Torah scholars enjoy good in this world], and the reward of a man's hand, He returns to him [i.e., and the principal remains for them for the world to come].
text.11_Chapter, 14_Verse: The way of the fool is just in his eyes — but he who heeds counsel is wise.
text.11_Chapter, 15_Verse: The fool, on the [very] day [that he is angered] makes known his anger [(by insulting his antagonist in public)], but the wise one conceals shame.
text.11_Chapter, 16_Verse: The [(habitual)] speaker of truth will testify justly, but the witness who [(habitually)] lies [will testify] deceitfully.
text.11_Chapter, 17_Verse: There are those whose speaking pierces like the sword [i.e., incites to strife], but the tongue of the wise [(who pursue peace)] "heals" [(that "speaking")].
text.11_Chapter, 18_Verse: True speech is established forever, but the false tongue for a moment only.
text.11_Chapter, 19_Verse: [Thoughts of] deceit [(which banish joy)] are in the heart of the plotters of evil, but in [the heart of] the counselors of peace [there is] joy.
text.11_Chapter, 20_Verse: No wrong [i.e., no unwitting transgression] will befall the righteous one, but the wicked are [unceasingly] filled with evil.
text.11_Chapter, 21_Verse: False lips are an abomination to the L-rd, and those who act in faith are His desire.
text.11_Chapter, 22_Verse: The wise man conceals [even his] wisdom, and the heart of the fools calls out foolishness.
text.11_Chapter, 23_Verse: The hand of the just shall prosper, but [that of] deceivers shall melt.
text.11_Chapter, 24_Verse: [If there is] sorrow in a man's heart, let him banish it [(from his mind)], and a good thing [i.e., Torah] will convert it to joy.
text.11_Chapter, 25_Verse: More yielding than his neighbor is the righteous one, and the way of the wicked leads them astray, [and, as a result],
text.11_Chapter, 26_Verse: he [(the wicked one)] will not [get to] roast his game [caught by his] deceit; but the wealth of an honest man is precious [and enduring].
text.11_Chapter, 27_Verse: On the road of righteousness there is life, and in its pathway, no death.
text.12_Chapter, 0_Verse: A wise son [loves] the mussar of [his] father, but a scoffer does not hear [i.e., accept] rebuke.
text.12_Chapter, 1_Verse: From the fruit of a man's mouth [i.e., as the reward of his Torah], he will eat good [(in this world, with the principal remaining for the world to come)], but the desire of the faithless is violence.
text.12_Chapter, 2_Verse: He who guards his mouth guards his soul; he who opens wide his lips [(to speak his fill, always)], it is breaking to him.
text.12_Chapter, 3_Verse: The soul of the sluggard lusts [for everything] and has nothing, but the soul of the just [(who eat of the toil of their hands)] is fatted.
text.12_Chapter, 4_Verse: The righteous one hates a false report, but the wicked one shames and sullies [(men with it)].
text.12_Chapter, 5_Verse: Charity will guard him who walks in innocence, but [his] wickedness will pervert the sinner.
text.12_Chapter, 6_Verse: Some flaunt wealth, having nothing, and others [flaunt] poverty, having great wealth.
text.12_Chapter, 7_Verse: A man's wealth [(when giving charity)] may redeem his soul — [but only] when the poor man hears no rebuke [in receiving it].
text.12_Chapter, 8_Verse: The light [i.e., the soul] of the righteous will rejoice, but the lamp of the wicked will flicker out.
text.12_Chapter, 9_Verse: Only by the willful is strife fomented, but among those who take counsel, there is wisdom [(and peace)].
text.12_Chapter, 10_Verse: Wealth [i.e., Torah] [accumulated] in "bundles" will diminish, but that gathered by the hand [i.e., by patient study and review] will increase.
text.12_Chapter, 11_Verse: A drawn out hope [i.e., trusting in vain to one's friend)] sickens the heart, but a tree of life is desire attained.
text.12_Chapter, 12_Verse: One who cheapens a thing [(of Torah)] will be taken in pledge for it, but he who fears a mitzvah will be paid [i.e., rewarded].
text.12_Chapter, 13_Verse: The Torah of the wise man is a well of life, [(teaching him)] to turn away from the snares of death [i.e., sins].
text.12_Chapter, 14_Verse: Right understanding invests one with grace, but the way of the faithless is strong [i.e., severe to him and to others].
text.12_Chapter, 15_Verse: Every wise man proceeds with discretion, but the fool broadcasts [his] folly.
text.12_Chapter, 16_Verse: A wicked messenger will fall into evil [(e.g., Bilam [Numbers 22:35])], but the faithful emissary [(Moses)] enhances [(his commission)].
text.12_Chapter, 17_Verse: Poverty and shame [come to him] who casts aside mussar, but he who heeds rebuke will be honored.
text.12_Chapter, 18_Verse: Lust realized is sweet to the soul — [wherefore] it is the abomination of fools to turn away from evil.
text.12_Chapter, 19_Verse: He who walks with the wise will grow wise, but the befriender of fools will be broken.
text.12_Chapter, 20_Verse: [Their] evil will pursue the sinners [(until they are destroyed by it)], and the righteous will be paid [i.e., rewarded] by [their] good.
text.12_Chapter, 21_Verse: The good [man] bequeaths [(his merits and his wealth)] to [his] grandchildren, but the wealth of the sinner is secreted for the righteous one.
text.12_Chapter, 22_Verse: Much food [comes to the world through] the plowing of the poor [i.e., Much Torah is produced by the disciples ("the poor"), whose teachers ("the rich") "plow" them with pilpul (dialectic)], but there are [those of them] who perish for lack of judgment [i.e., for improper deportment].
text.12_Chapter, 23_Verse: He who spares his rod [will come] to hate his child [(for improper deportment)], but he who loves him chastises him betimes.
text.12_Chapter, 24_Verse: The righteous one eats to [(what he perceives as)] the satiety of his soul, but the stomach of the wicked [(in their mind)] is [always] lacking.
text.13_Chapter, 0_Verse: The wisest of the women builds her house, and the foolish one destroys it with her own hands.
text.13_Chapter, 1_Verse: He who fears the L-rd walks in uprightness, and he who is perverse in his ways shames Him.
text.13_Chapter, 2_Verse: In the fool is the stick of pride, but the lips of the wise will guard them.
text.13_Chapter, 3_Verse: Where there are no oxen, the manger is clean — but there is much produce in the strength of the ox. [(Where there are no Torah scholars, the teaching is not in accordance with the halachah)].
text.13_Chapter, 4_Verse: The honest witness will not deceive, but the false witness spouts deceptions.
text.13_Chapter, 5_Verse: The scoffer will seek wisdom [(when he requires it)] and not find it [in his heart], but wisdom will come easily to the understanding one.
text.13_Chapter, 6_Verse: Go far away from the foolish man [i.e., do not befriend him], or you will not know lips of wisdom.
text.13_Chapter, 7_Verse: The wisdom of the wise one is understanding his way [i.e., weighing his decisions]; the folly of the fools is [the] deceit [in their hearts (which prompts them to folly)].
text.13_Chapter, 8_Verse: [Monetary] reparations [(to those they have offended)] will plead for the fools, [(viz.  Samuel 6:4)], but among the just [(G-d and His people)] good will [(will suffice)].
text.13_Chapter, 9_Verse: The heart knows its own toil [(in the study of Torah)], and [(therefore)] in its joy [i.e., its reward in the future] no stranger will share.
text.13_Chapter, 10_Verse: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, and the tent of the just will blossom.
text.13_Chapter, 11_Verse: There is a way [(of transgression)] which is just in a man's eyes, but whose end is the ways of death.
text.13_Chapter, 12_Verse: Even with play [(the "play" of the L-rd with the idolators in this world)], the heart [(of the idolators)] will grieve [(in the world to come [viz. Isaiah 65:14])] so that its end will be joy [turned to] sorrow.
text.13_Chapter, 13_Verse: The impure of heart [(Esav)] shall be sated [i.e., punished] with his ways, and the good man [(Yaakov)] [will depart] from him [(not to share in his punishment)].
text.13_Chapter, 14_Verse: The fool believes everything [(reported by talebearers)], but the wise man looks to his steps [(i.e., he ascertains the truth before acting on what he hears)].
text.13_Chapter, 15_Verse: The wise man fears [punishment] and turns away from the evil, but the fool forges on and falls.
text.13_Chapter, 16_Verse: He who is quick to vent his wrath is rendered foolish thereby, and the man who plots evil is hated.
text.13_Chapter, 17_Verse: The fools have inherited folly, and the wise will crown [themselves with] wisdom, [and, in the end,]
text.13_Chapter, 18_Verse: the evildoers will grovel before the good, and the wicked, at the gates of the righteous one.
text.13_Chapter, 19_Verse: Even by his comrade is the ignorant [(coarse)] man hated, and the lovers of the rich are many.
text.13_Chapter, 20_Verse: He who shames his friend is a sinner, and he who is gracious to the poor, fortunate is he.
text.13_Chapter, 21_Verse: Will not the devisers of evil stray, and lovingkindness and truth [greet] the devisers of good?
text.13_Chapter, 22_Verse: In all toil there is gain, but the word of the lips [i.e., vain talk] is for loss alone.
text.13_Chapter, 23_Verse: The crown of the wise is their wealth [(in Torah)]; the undoing of the fools is their folly [(their laxity in learning)].
text.13_Chapter, 24_Verse: A true witness is the saver of souls, and the spouter of lies [saves the man of] deceit.
text.13_Chapter, 25_Verse: The fear of the L-rd is a bastion of strength [viz. Genesis 22:12 and 17], and he [(the G-d-fearing man)] will be shelter for his sons.
text.13_Chapter, 26_Verse: The fear of the L-rd is a source of life to turn [one away] from the snares of death.
text.13_Chapter, 27_Verse: In the multitude of the people [(when they are meritorious)] is the glory of the King, and in the want of a [(virtuous)] populace is the waning of [His] princehood [i.e., majesty].
text.13_Chapter, 28_Verse: He who is slow to wrath [gains] much understanding, but he who is short-tempered garners folly.
text.13_Chapter, 29_Verse: The life of [creatures of] flesh is a healing heart [(a heart of flesh, which "heals" the evil by yielding and forgiving)], but a rotting of the bones [(of mankind)] is a man of scorn.
text.13_Chapter, 30_Verse: He who robs the poor man shames his Maker, but he who is gracious to the needy one honors Him.
text.13_Chapter, 31_Verse: The wicked man is cast out by his evil, and the righteous one takes shelter [(in the L-rd)] in his death [(knowing that he will come to Eden)].
text.13_Chapter, 32_Verse: In the understanding heart, wisdom will repose, and in the midst of the fools, it [(the modicum of wisdom that they may possess)] will clamor.
text.13_Chapter, 33_Verse: Charity will uplift the nation [(Israel)], and the lovingkindness of the peoples, [(who steal from one and give to another)] is a sin.
text.13_Chapter, 34_Verse: The favor of the king [will be] upon the wise servant, and his wrath, upon the shameful one.
text.14_Chapter, 0_Verse: A soft answer turns away wrath, but a galling response raises wrath.
text.14_Chapter, 1_Verse: The tongue of the wise will perfect wisdom, but the mouth of fools will spout folly.
text.14_Chapter, 2_Verse: In every place, the eyes of the L-rd see the evil and the good.
text.14_Chapter, 3_Verse: A soft tongue is a tree of life, but perverseness with it [leads to] breaking by the [(east)] wind.
text.14_Chapter, 4_Verse: The fool despises the mussar of his father, but he who guards chastisement will grow wise.
text.14_Chapter, 5_Verse: The house of the righteous one [i.e., the Temple, built by David] is a tower of strength [(to Israel)], but with the entrance of wickedness [(the idolatry brought there by Menasheh)] it is polluted.
text.14_Chapter, 6_Verse: The lips of the wise crown wisdom; not so, the heart of fools.
text.14_Chapter, 7_Verse: The offering of the wicked [(Balak and Bilam)] is an abomination to the L-rd, and the prayer of the just [(Moses)] is His desire.
text.14_Chapter, 8_Verse: The path of the wicked is an abomination to the L-rd, and he who pursues righteousness is beloved by Him.
text.14_Chapter, 9_Verse: Severe afflictions await the forsaker of the path [of the L-rd]; the hater of chastisement will die.
text.14_Chapter, 10_Verse: The grave and perdition [i.e., Gehinnom] are revealed to the L-rd; how much more so the hearts of men.
text.14_Chapter, 11_Verse: The fool does not like being chastised; he will not go to the wise.
text.14_Chapter, 12_Verse: A happy heart brightens the Countenance [i.e., If one gladdens the L-rd's heart (by walking in His ways), He will look with favor upon him and do His will)], but saddening of [His] heart, [rouses] a spirit of anger.
text.14_Chapter, 13_Verse: An understanding heart will pursue wisdom, but the mouth of fools will befriend folly.
text.14_Chapter, 14_Verse: All the days of the poor man [(even Sabbaths and festivals)] are evil [("A change of regimen brings on intestinal disorder")]; but the good-hearted [i.e., one who is happy with what he possesses] (enjoys) a perpetual feast.
text.14_Chapter, 15_Verse: Better a little gained through fear of the L-rd than a great treasure amassed over [the] cries [of the despoiled].
text.14_Chapter, 16_Verse: Better a meal of greens [(given to the poor)] where there is love than a fattened ox where there is hatred.
text.14_Chapter, 17_Verse: The man of wrath incites strife, and the patient of spirit quiets a quarrel [(in the bud)].
text.14_Chapter, 18_Verse: The way of the sluggard is fenced with thorns [(in his eyes)], but the path of the just is paved.
text.14_Chapter, 19_Verse: The wise son rejoices his father, and the fool among men brings shame upon his mother.
text.14_Chapter, 20_Verse: Folly is joy to him who lacks a heart, but the man of understanding [will rejoice] when he walks justly.
text.14_Chapter, 21_Verse: Thoughts are voided for lack of counsel, and in an abundance of counselors they are established.
text.14_Chapter, 22_Verse: A man rejoices in the answer of his mouth [i.e., a soft reply causes men to love him], and a word in its time [i.e., apt responses to inquiries on festival halachoth] — how good it is!
text.14_Chapter, 23_Verse: A path of life [is readied] for the wise man above, so that his soul turn away from Sheol beneath.
text.14_Chapter, 24_Verse: The L-rd will uproot the dwelling of the proud and establish [in its place] the boundary of the widow.
text.14_Chapter, 25_Verse: The abomination of the L-rd is [soft speech with] wicked thoughts; words of pleasantness [should be entirely] pure.
text.14_Chapter, 26_Verse: He who steals sullies his home, but the hater [even] of gifts [(and not only of theft)] will live.
text.14_Chapter, 27_Verse: The heart of the righteous one will consider [what] to answer, but the mouth of the wicked will spout evils.
text.14_Chapter, 28_Verse: The L-rd is far from the wicked, but He will hear the prayer of the righteous.
text.14_Chapter, 29_Verse: The [de-] light of the eyes [(such as green gardens and flowing rivers)] rejoices the heart [(and dispels sadness)]; a good report fattens the bone.
text.14_Chapter, 30_Verse: The ear that attends to the reproof [that brings] life will come to abide in the midst of the wise.
text.14_Chapter, 31_Verse: He who rejects mussar despises his soul, and he who listens to reproof acquires understanding.
text.14_Chapter, 32_Verse: The fear of the L-rd is chastisement [(towards the acquisition)] of wisdom, and humility leads to honor.
text.15_Chapter, 0_Verse: A man arranges [his brief in his] heart, but from the L-rd is the utterance of his tongue [(in expressing it, whether for smoothness or for stumbling)].
text.15_Chapter, 1_Verse: All of a man's ways are pure in his eyes, but the L-rd counts the spirits [(of men and evaluates them)].
text.15_Chapter, 2_Verse: Cast your deeds [i.e., the fulfillment of your needs] upon the L-rd, and all your thoughts will be set aright.
text.15_Chapter, 3_Verse: The L-rd created all for His praise — even the evildoer for the day of retribution.
text.15_Chapter, 4_Verse: The abomination of the L-rd is every one who is haughty of heart; [punishment will come from G-d's] hand to [his] hand. He will not go clean.
text.15_Chapter, 5_Verse: Through lovingkindness and truth sin is forgiven, and through fear of the L-rd [there is] turning from evil.
text.15_Chapter, 6_Verse: When the L-rd desires a man's ways, his foes, too, He will conciliate unto him.
text.15_Chapter, 7_Verse: Better a little [gained] through righteousness than much produce without justice.
text.15_Chapter, 8_Verse: A man's heart will consider his way [(to walk the right path)], and the L-rd will set his steps aright.
text.15_Chapter, 9_Verse: There is a charm on the lips of a king [(a Torah sage sitting in judgment)]; his mouth will not deceive in judgment.
text.15_Chapter, 10_Verse: A scale and just balances are the L-rd's [(to recompense a man according to his deeds)]. His deeds [(of requital are performed as with)] all pocket stones [(weights), commensurate with the deeds of men.]
text.15_Chapter, 11_Verse: It is an abomination for kings [i.e., judges] to do evil, for it is through righteousness that a throne is established.
text.15_Chapter, 12_Verse: The desire of kings is righteous words, and just speech is beloved [of them].
text.15_Chapter, 13_Verse: The wrath of kings [is like] angels of death, and the wise man will appease it.
text.15_Chapter, 14_Verse: In the light [i.e., the favor] of the King's countenance, there is life [(so that it behooves one to straighten his paths before Him)]; and His favor is as the cloud [bringing] the latter rains.
text.15_Chapter, 15_Verse: How much better is the acquisition of silver than fine gold, and the acquisition of understanding, [how much] more select than silver.
text.15_Chapter, 16_Verse: The path of the just is departing from evil. The keeper of his soul guards his way.
text.15_Chapter, 17_Verse: Pride comes before the fall, and haughtiness of spirit before failure.
text.15_Chapter, 18_Verse: Better [to keep company] with the humble [in] lowliness of spirit than to share spoil with the proud.
text.15_Chapter, 19_Verse: He who deliberates over a thing [i.e., he who gives heart to his ways] will find good; and trusting to the L-rd [(where there is risk of loss in pursuing a mitzvah)] is his praise.
text.15_Chapter, 20_Verse: The wise of heart [(he who has acquired wisdom from his teacher)] will be called "understanding" [(when he generates new ideas from this wisdom)], and he who "sweetens" [his learning, making it cogent in imparting it] with his lips, will [himself] gain in knowledge.
text.15_Chapter, 21_Verse: A well of life is wisdom to its possessor, and folly is chastisement to the fools.
text.15_Chapter, 22_Verse: The sage's heart makes his mouth wise, and from his lips he grows in knowledge.
text.15_Chapter, 23_Verse: Words of pleasantness [i.e., words of Torah] are a honeycomb; sweet to the soul and healing to the body.
text.15_Chapter, 24_Verse: There is a way that is just in the eyes of man, but whose end is the ways of death.
text.15_Chapter, 25_Verse: The toiling spirit will have toiled for itself [i.e., for its own benefit] when its mouth makes demands upon it.
text.15_Chapter, 26_Verse: The wicked man plots evil, and it burns like a fire on his lips [(until he expresses it [i.e., until he brings it to fruition])].
text.15_Chapter, 27_Verse: The man of contraries incites strife, and the complainer [(through his complaints)] estranges the Regent.
text.15_Chapter, 28_Verse: The man of violence entices his companion and leads him in a way that is not good.
text.15_Chapter, 29_Verse: One who blinks with his eyes to plot perverseness, one who "blinks" with his lips, has consummated evil.
text.15_Chapter, 30_Verse: A crown of glory is the hoary head; in the way of righteousness it will be found.
text.15_Chapter, 31_Verse: Greater is the withholder of [his] wrath than the hero, and the ruler of his spirit [i.e., the conqueror of his evil inclination] than the conqueror of a city.
text.15_Chapter, 32_Verse: In [his] lap one casts the lot [(deeming himself the shaper of his fate)] — when all of his judgment [has been "cast"] by the L-rd.
text.16_Chapter, 0_Verse: Better a dry loaf and peace with it than a house full of slaughtered [meat in the midst of] contention [i.e., It was better for the L-rd to destroy His Temple and His city and be at peace from the transgressions of Israel than to have them sacrifice offerings therein in the midst of strife].
text.16_Chapter, 1_Verse: The wise servant [(Nevuchadnezzar)] will rule over the shameful son [(Israel)] and in the midst of brothers will apportion the inheritance [(to himself)].
text.16_Chapter, 2_Verse: The refining pot for [assaying and refining] silver, and the crucible for gold, but the L-rd assays hearts.
text.16_Chapter, 3_Verse: The wicked man listens to iniquitous speech [(slander and false testimony)]; the false man listens to the destroying tongue.
text.16_Chapter, 4_Verse: He who mocks the poor man insults his Maker; he who rejoices in [another's] misfortune will not be clean [of it himself].
text.16_Chapter, 5_Verse: The crown of the old are grandchildren [(who walk in the way of good)], and the glory of children are their fathers [(who are righteous)].
text.16_Chapter, 6_Verse: Lofty speech does not become the churl; how much more so, lying speech the noble one.
text.16_Chapter, 7_Verse: A precious stone is appeasement [(of the L-rd)] in the eyes of his [(the appeaser's, the penitent's,)] Master. Wherever he turns [i.e., in whatever he asks of Him], He will prosper [him].
text.16_Chapter, 8_Verse: One who conceals an offense [done against him (by not mentioning it)] seeks love [i.e., causes the offender to love him], and one who repeats a thing [i.e., one who always brings up the offense to his face] divorces the Ruler [from himself].
text.16_Chapter, 9_Verse: The humbling [effect] of a rebuke in an understanding person [is more evident] than [the effect of] a hundred blows to the fool.
text.16_Chapter, 10_Verse: The rebellious one seeks only evil, and a cruel angel will be sent against him.
text.16_Chapter, 11_Verse: Better to be met by a bear bereaved [(of its cubs)] than by a fool [(an idolator)] in his folly [(enticing to idolatry)].
text.16_Chapter, 12_Verse: One who returns evil for good — evil will not depart from his house.
text.16_Chapter, 13_Verse: As opening [the way for] water [to escape] is beginning a quarrel; before it [(your shame)] is revealed, abandon it [(the quarrel)].
text.16_Chapter, 14_Verse: Justifying an evildoer and condemning the righteous one — both of these are the abomination of the L-rd.
text.16_Chapter, 15_Verse: Of what use is payment in the hand of a fool to acquire wisdom [(Torah)] if the heart [(to fulfill it)] is lacking [(and he learns it only to acquire a name)]?
text.16_Chapter, 16_Verse: At all times love friends [(to acquire them)], and a brother in [a time of] affliction will he be born.
text.16_Chapter, 17_Verse: The man lacking a heart clasps hands, going security for his friend.
text.16_Chapter, 18_Verse: One who loves to offend [(his neighbor)] loves to quarrel; one who lifts his voice [in pride] seeks breaking.
text.16_Chapter, 19_Verse: The perverse of heart will not find good, and he who turns away [his true intent] with his tongue will fall into the evil [he plotted against the other].
text.16_Chapter, 20_Verse: One who has begotten a fool has done so to his sorrow, and the father of a churl will not rejoice.
text.16_Chapter, 21_Verse: A happy heart [(in contentment with one's lot)] heightens shining [(of countenance)], but a broken spirit dries the bone.
text.16_Chapter, 22_Verse: He [(the L-rd)] accepts appeasement from the recesses of the wicked one [(i.e., in secret)] to turn the paths of judgment [(from severity to lenity)].
text.16_Chapter, 23_Verse: Wisdom lies before the understanding one [i.e., he perceives it as easily accessible to him]; but the eyes of the fool [vis-à-vis] wisdom are in the ends of the earth.
text.16_Chapter, 24_Verse: A foolish son is ire to his father [(e.g., Yeravam to the L-rd)] and bitterness to her who bore him [(i.e., to the congregation of Israel, whom he caused to sin)].
text.16_Chapter, 25_Verse: To punish the righteous, too, [(along with the wicked)] is not good [viz. I Kings 19:18], to smite the noble in [their] justness.
text.16_Chapter, 26_Verse: The knower of wisdom spares his words; the man of understanding is chary of breath [i.e., speech].
text.16_Chapter, 27_Verse: Even one who silences a fool is accounted wise; one who stops up his [the fool's] lips [is accounted] understanding.
text.17_Chapter, 0_Verse: One who departs [from the L-rd] to court lust will be exposed in every Torah conclave.
text.17_Chapter, 1_Verse: The fool does not desire understanding, but to "ventilate" his heart.
text.17_Chapter, 2_Verse: With the coming of the wicked one, there also comes contempt, and with profligacy, shaming.
text.17_Chapter, 3_Verse: Deep waters are the words of a hero, a flowing stream, the wellspring of wisdom.
text.17_Chapter, 4_Verse: It is not good for the wicked that favor is shown [them in this world and punishment exacted in the next.] [It is good] for the righteous that [the scales of] judgment are turned [against them in this world, so that they merit life in the world to come].
text.17_Chapter, 5_Verse: The lips of the fool [i.e., all of his words] come in [terms of] quarrel, and his mouth invites blows.
text.17_Chapter, 6_Verse: The mouth of a fool brings destruction to him, and his lips are a stumbling-block to his soul.
text.17_Chapter, 7_Verse: The words of the complainer are like blows and they enter one's innards.
text.17_Chapter, 8_Verse: Even he [(a Torah scholar)] who weakens in his work [(i.e., who departs from the Torah)] is a brother to the destroyer [(Satan)].
text.17_Chapter, 9_Verse: A tower of strength is the name of the L-rd. Through it the righteous one will race [whithersoever he wishes], and he will be strengthened [therein].
text.17_Chapter, 10_Verse: The treasure of the wealthy one is the city of his strength; as a fortified wall [is it] in his chamber.
text.17_Chapter, 11_Verse: Before destruction a man's heart grows haughty, and before honor there is humility.
text.17_Chapter, 12_Verse: If one answers before he has heard, it will be accounted foolishness to him, and shame.
text.17_Chapter, 13_Verse: A hero's spirit will sustain his sickness [(and it will not prevail over him)]; but a broken spirit, who will bear it?
text.17_Chapter, 14_Verse: An understanding heart will acquire wisdom [of itself], but the ear of the wise will seek wisdom.
text.17_Chapter, 15_Verse: A man's gift will broaden [the path] for him and will lead him before the great.
text.17_Chapter, 16_Verse: The first [to state his case] in an argument seems righteous; but when his fellow comes, he is interrogated [in distrust].
text.17_Chapter, 17_Verse: A lottery can quell a quarrel and part the litigants [in their dispute].
text.17_Chapter, 18_Verse: [There is] a brother who, by his rebellion [(against his brother)], [is deprived] of a bastion of strength [(e.g., Lot against Abraham, Esav against Jacob)], and [whose] quarrel [separates them forever] as the bolt of palace [doors forbids entry].
text.17_Chapter, 19_Verse: A man's stomach will be sated with the fruits of his mouth; he will be sated with the produce of his lips.
text.17_Chapter, 20_Verse: Life and death are in the power of the tongue; those who love [to use] it [in the study of Torah] will eat its fruit [in the world to come].
text.17_Chapter, 21_Verse: He who has found a wife has found good and has brought forth favor from the L-rd.
text.17_Chapter, 22_Verse: The poor man speaks imploringly [though he knows that] the rich man will answer brazenly.
text.17_Chapter, 23_Verse: A man [acquires] friends to befriend [him in time of need], for sometimes a lover [i.e., a friend] will cleave [to him] more than a brother.
text.18_Chapter, 0_Verse: Better a poor man who walks in his innocence than one who perverts his lips and is a fool.
text.18_Chapter, 1_Verse: Also, without wisdom [i.e., Torah] it is not good [for] the soul; and the sinner treads [transgressions] underfoot [(saying: "This is only a slight sin and I will do it.")]
text.18_Chapter, 2_Verse: A man's folly perverts his way and his heart rants against the L-rd! [viz., Joseph's brothers (Genesis 42:28)]
text.18_Chapter, 3_Verse: Wealth adds many friends, but a poor man is parted from his fellow [by his poverty].
text.18_Chapter, 4_Verse: The false witness will not be clean [(of Heavenly judgment)], and the spouter of lies will not escape.
text.18_Chapter, 5_Verse: Many court the presence of the patron, and all befriend the man of gifts.
text.18_Chapter, 6_Verse: All the kin of the poor man hate him — How much more so do his friends withdraw from him! He pursues words which are naught [i.e., vain, saying: "So and so is my relative; so and so is my friend."]
text.18_Chapter, 7_Verse: One who acquires understanding loves his soul; the guarder of understanding will find good.
text.18_Chapter, 8_Verse: The false witness will not be clean [(of Heavenly judgment)], and the spouter of lies will go lost.
text.18_Chapter, 9_Verse: Pleasure does not befit a fool; how much more so [does it not befit] a servant to lord it over dignitaries.
text.18_Chapter, 10_Verse: It is wisdom in a man to withhold his wrath, and his glory is overlooking offense.
text.18_Chapter, 11_Verse: As the roar of a young lion is the wrath of the King, and as dew upon grass is His [good] will.
text.18_Chapter, 12_Verse: A father's heartbreak is a foolish son, and [like] a harrowing drip is a woman's contentions.
text.18_Chapter, 13_Verse: A house and wealth is an inheritance from fathers, but a wise woman comes from the L-rd.
text.18_Chapter, 14_Verse: Laziness casts a slumber, and the deceiving soul will go hungry.
text.18_Chapter, 15_Verse: One who keeps a mitzvah keeps his soul. One who is heedless of his ways [(not taking care to weigh them)] will die.
text.18_Chapter, 16_Verse: He who is gracious to the poor has lent to the L-rd, and He will pay him his reward.
text.18_Chapter, 17_Verse: Chastise your son, for there is hope, but do not turn your soul to killing him.
text.18_Chapter, 18_Verse: [If you] suppress [your] wrath [against your foe and] rescue [him when you see him] coming to harm, you will grow yet more [in years and in good].
text.18_Chapter, 19_Verse: Hear counsel and accept chastisement in order to grow wise in your later days.
text.18_Chapter, 20_Verse: There are many thoughts in a man's heart, but the counsel of the L-rd, it will prevail.
text.18_Chapter, 21_Verse: A man is desired because of his [expected] lovingkindness, but a poor man [who does not promise at all] is better than a [rich] man who deceives.
text.18_Chapter, 22_Verse: The fear of the L-rd is [(a cause)] for life, and he [(its possessor)] will rest sated and not be visited with [any] evil.
text.18_Chapter, 23_Verse: The lazy man hides his hand in the [hot] kettle [(to warm it)]; not even to his mouth does he return it.
text.18_Chapter, 24_Verse: You smite the scoffer and the understanding one grows wise [(Through the plagues against Pharaoh and the war with Amalek Yithro grew wise and became a proselyte)]. Chastise the understanding one and he will understand [(even more)] knowledge.
text.18_Chapter, 25_Verse: He despoils [his] father and drives away [his] mother — a son who shames and confounds [his ways]. [(Because Sarah saw Yishmael corrupting his ways, she drove him out together with his mother, Hagar, grieving Abraham thereby)].
text.18_Chapter, 26_Verse: Forbear, my son, from straying from words of wisdom, in order to hear mussar.
text.18_Chapter, 27_Verse: The perverse witness spouts justice, but blight will devour the mouth of the wicked.
text.18_Chapter, 28_Verse: Judgments are readied for the scoffers [(The L-rd has readied judgments of leprosy for the scoffing slanderers)], and blows for the backs of fools.
text.19_Chapter, 0_Verse: [The drinker of] wine is a scoffer; [one who drinks] strong drink will cry out, and all who err therein [thinking that much wine will produce sound judgment] will not grow wise.
text.19_Chapter, 1_Verse: As the roar of a young lion, so is the fear of the king [to his subject]; one who angers him diminishes [i.e., endangers] his soul.
text.19_Chapter, 2_Verse: A man's honor is to abstain from a quarrel, and [the shame of] every man [who does not abstain from it] will be revealed [through it].
text.19_Chapter, 3_Verse: Because of the [cold of] winter the sluggard will not plow [i.e., he will not engage in the study of Torah]. He will desire it at harvest time, but it will not be there.
text.19_Chapter, 4_Verse: [Like] deep waters is counsel in the heart of a man [i.e., the halachah is concealed in the heart of the sage], and the man of understanding [(a knowing disciple)] will draw them forth.
text.19_Chapter, 5_Verse: Many men call upon the man [in whom they trust for] lovingkindness, but who will find a man of trust?
