text.19_Chapter, 6_Verse: He who walks in his innocence is a righteous man; fortunate are his sons after him.
text.19_Chapter, 7_Verse: When the King sits on the seat of judgment, all evil is spread out before His eyes.
text.19_Chapter, 8_Verse: Who can say: "My heart is clean"? "I have purified myself from my sin"?
text.19_Chapter, 9_Verse: A [large] stone and a [small] stone; a [large] measure and a [small] measure — both of them are the abomination of the L-rd.
text.19_Chapter, 10_Verse: Even the youth in his youthful deeds can cause wonder as to whether his acts be pure and just.
text.19_Chapter, 11_Verse: The hearing ear and the seeing eye — G-d made both of these [(and He desires an ear that hears mussar and an eye that sees the future)].
text.19_Chapter, 12_Verse: Do not love sleep lest you grow poor. Open your eyes and be sated with bread.
text.19_Chapter, 13_Verse: "Bad, bad," says the [prospective] buyer, but when he walks away [with purchase in hand], he vaunts himself [for his acumen]. [(One who acquires Torah under duress bemoans his hard lot, but when he emerges full of wisdom, his past suffering is a source of gratification to him.)]
text.19_Chapter, 14_Verse: There is [much] gold and many pearls, but lips of wisdom are a precious vessel.
text.19_Chapter, 15_Verse: Take [(without compunction)] the garment of him who goes security for a stranger, and take his security for an alien woman.
text.19_Chapter, 16_Verse: The "bread of falsehood" [i.e., adultery] is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth will be filled with gravel.
text.19_Chapter, 17_Verse: Thoughts [conceived] in counsel will endure, and wage war [against Satan] with stratagems [(of penitence, prayer, and fasting)].
text.19_Chapter, 18_Verse: The revealer of secrets, the bearer of tales, and the "smooth talker" — do not befriend them.
text.19_Chapter, 19_Verse: He who curses his father and his mother, his light [i.e., his soul] will flicker out in the pith of darkness [i.e., when evil befalls him].
text.19_Chapter, 20_Verse: An inheritance pursued in haste in the beginning [e.g., that of the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuven (viz. Numbers 32:16)] will not be blessed in the end. [(They were exiled several years before the other tribes.)]
text.19_Chapter, 21_Verse: Do not say: "I will repay evil [after its kind]." Hope in the L-rd and He will help you.
text.19_Chapter, 22_Verse: The abomination of the L-rd is a [large] stone and a [small] stone, and scales of deceit are not good [in His eyes].
text.19_Chapter, 23_Verse: A man's steps are from the L-rd, but what does a man know of his way?
text.19_Chapter, 24_Verse: When a man stumbles [in sin], he undermines [his] holiness, and he must seek out vows [i.e., offerings through which to find atonement].
text.19_Chapter, 25_Verse: The wise King scatters the wicked [(Pharaoh and his hosts)], and he turns the wheel [back] upon them [(recompensing them measure for measure)].
text.19_Chapter, 26_Verse: The lamp of the L-rd is a man's soul [(it testifies concerning him in judgment)]; it seeks out all [his] hidden recesses.
text.19_Chapter, 27_Verse: Lovingkindness and truth guard a king, and he sustains his throne in lovingkindness.
text.19_Chapter, 28_Verse: The beauty of youths is their strength, and the glory of the old is [their] hoariness.
text.19_Chapter, 29_Verse: Bruises [and] wounds [come upon] one who consecrates himself to evil, and "blows [in his] innards" [i.e., dropsy.]
text.20_Chapter, 0_Verse: As water courses [in the hands of a man], so is the heart of a king in the hand of the L-rd. Whithersoever He wishes, He inclines it.
text.20_Chapter, 1_Verse: A man's every way is just in his eyes, but the L-rd counts the hearts.
text.20_Chapter, 2_Verse: The doing of righteousness and justice is choicer to the L-rd than a sacrifice.
text.20_Chapter, 3_Verse: Haughtiness of eye and swelling of heart [i.e., desire to satisfy lust] is the plotting of the wicked, [and it is their] sin.
text.20_Chapter, 4_Verse: The thoughts of the upright are for gain alone, and all who are precipitate reap only loss.
text.20_Chapter, 5_Verse: The amassing of treasures with a false tongue is a smitten vapor; [they (the treasures) are] snares of death.
text.20_Chapter, 6_Verse: The theft of the wicked affrights them, for they refuse to deal justly [(by returning what they have stolen)].
text.20_Chapter, 7_Verse: Crooked is the way of a man who is strange [to mitzvoth]; but the pure one, his work is just.
text.20_Chapter, 8_Verse: Better to dwell on a rooftop corner than [to have] a contentious wife and [one who enters his] friend's house [to converse with his wife].
text.20_Chapter, 9_Verse: The soul of the evildoer desires evil [knowing that it is evil, and therefore,] his companion [in evil] will not find favor in his eyes.
text.20_Chapter, 10_Verse: When the scoffer is punished, the simple one gains wisdom [and repents]; and when the wise one receives instruction, he gains wisdom.
text.20_Chapter, 11_Verse: The Righteous One eyes the house of the wicked [(e.g., Amalek) to destroy it)]; He relegates the wicked to ruin.
text.20_Chapter, 12_Verse: If one closes his ear to the pauper's cry, he, too, will call out and not be answered.
text.20_Chapter, 13_Verse: The hidden gift [(charity)] will cover up wrath, and a bribe in the bosom [(likewise, charity)] [will cover up] strong fury.
text.20_Chapter, 14_Verse: The doing of justice [(i.e., G-d's afflicting them)] is joy to the righteous [(in that it purges them for the world to come)], but it is breaking to the workers of iniquity [(in that they do not take heart to repent, so that the afflictions are "wasted" upon them)].
text.20_Chapter, 15_Verse: The man who wanders from the path of wisdom [(Torah)] will rest in the congregation of the shades [(Gehinnom)].
text.20_Chapter, 16_Verse: The lover of joy will be a man of want; the lover of wine and oil will not grow rich.
text.20_Chapter, 17_Verse: The wicked one will be ransom for the righteous one [e.g., Haman for Mordecai], and the faithless one for the just.
text.20_Chapter, 18_Verse: Better to dwell in a wasteland than with a contentious woman in the midst of anger.
text.20_Chapter, 19_Verse: A goodly treasure and oil [endure] in the abode of the wise, and the folly of man swallows it up [at once].
text.20_Chapter, 20_Verse: He who pursues righteousness and lovingkindness will find life, righteousness, and honor.
text.20_Chapter, 21_Verse: The wise one [(Moses)] went up to the city of the strong [(the angels)] and brought down the "strength of its trust" [i.e., the Torah].
text.20_Chapter, 22_Verse: One who guards his mouth and tongue [(from improper speech)] guards his soul from evil.
text.20_Chapter, 23_Verse: The wanton boaster, his name is "scoffer" [i.e., he is destined to become a scoffer.] He acts in the wrath of wantonness.
text.20_Chapter, 24_Verse: The lust of the sluggard [(to vegetate)] will kill him, for his hands will refuse to do.
text.20_Chapter, 25_Verse: The whole day he will court lust, though the Righteous One give him [all of his necessities] and not spare.
text.20_Chapter, 26_Verse: The offering of the wicked is an abomination; how much more so when they bring it with evil intent [e.g., the offerings of Balak and Bilam].
text.20_Chapter, 27_Verse: The deceitful witness will go lost, but the man who heeds ["You shall not testify falsely against your neighbor" (Exodus 20:13)] will speak forever.
text.20_Chapter, 28_Verse: The wicked man shows his brazenness in his wrath, but the upright one sets his paths aright.
text.20_Chapter, 29_Verse: There is no wisdom or understanding or counsel against the L-rd [(No honor is accorded the sage at the expense of desecration of the Name.)]
text.20_Chapter, 30_Verse: [Though] the horse be set for the day of war, the salvation is the L-rd's.
text.21_Chapter, 0_Verse: A [good] name is choicer than much wealth, and goodly favor than silver and gold.
text.21_Chapter, 1_Verse: The rich man and the poor man meet. [If the poor man asks for food and the rich man answers him harshly,] the L-rd makes all [anew. i.e., He makes the rich man poor and the poor man rich].
text.21_Chapter, 2_Verse: The wise man sees the evil [(the punishment for a transgression)] and hides [from it]; but the fools pass on [i.e., they transgress] and are punished.
text.21_Chapter, 3_Verse: In the path of humility comes fear of the L-rd, wealth, and honor, and life.
text.21_Chapter, 4_Verse: Thorns and snares [i.e., afflictions] are in the way of the perverse [i.e., they are readied for them]; the keeper of his soul will distance himself from them.
text.21_Chapter, 5_Verse: [If you] rear the youth in his way [(either good or evil)], even when he grows old, he will not depart from it.
text.21_Chapter, 6_Verse: The rich rule the poor [i.e., the ignorant are always dependent upon the Torah scholars], just as the debtor is a servant to the creditor.
text.21_Chapter, 7_Verse: The sower of wrong will reap wrong, and his grain-stalk [i.e., his strength] will wither.
text.21_Chapter, 8_Verse: The generous one will be blessed, for he has given of his bread to the poor.
text.21_Chapter, 9_Verse: Drive away the scoffer [(the evil inclination)] and strife will depart, and punishment and shame will cease.
text.21_Chapter, 10_Verse: He [the L-rd] loves the pure of heart; [one who has] favor [on] his lips, the King befriends him.
text.21_Chapter, 11_Verse: The eyes of the L-rd guard wisdom, and He twists the words of the faithless.
text.21_Chapter, 12_Verse: The lazy one, [(shirking Torah study)], says: "There is a lion outside; in the midst of the streets I will be slain!" [(How can I go out to learn?)]
text.21_Chapter, 13_Verse: A deep pit is the mouth of the strange woman [(the idolatress)]; the scorned of the L-rd will fall therein.
text.21_Chapter, 14_Verse: Foolishness is rooted in the heart of a youth; the rod of chastisement will distance it from him.
text.21_Chapter, 15_Verse: He who robs the poor to increase [his fortune] will [ultimately] give [his wealth] to the rich [pagan kings, so that his greed will redound] to [his own] want.
text.21_Chapter, 16_Verse: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise [(though they be only moderately wise)], but put your heart to My mind [(i.e., If your teacher is wicked, do not learn from him.)]
text.21_Chapter, 17_Verse: For [it will be] pleasant [for you] if you keep them in your innards. [And when will you keep them so, (not to forget them)?] When they are established together upon your lips [i.e., when you utter them with your mouth.]
text.21_Chapter, 18_Verse: I have counseled you to put your trust in the L-rd [and to study Torah, without worrying how you will support yourself], today, even you!
text.21_Chapter, 19_Verse: Have I not written for you three-fold [(Torah, Prophets, Writings)] with counsel and wisdom?
text.21_Chapter, 20_Verse: To apprise you of the truth of words of truth, to return words of truth to those who send [to] you [for instruction].
text.21_Chapter, 21_Verse: Do not rob a poor man because he is poor [i.e., because you see him to be defenseless]; and do not crush a poor man in the gate [of judgment].
text.21_Chapter, 22_Verse: For the L-rd will fight their battle, and He will steal the soul of those who would steal from them.
text.21_Chapter, 23_Verse: Do not befriend the angry man, and do not come together with the man of wrath.
text.21_Chapter, 24_Verse: Lest you learn his ways and take a snare for your soul.
text.21_Chapter, 25_Verse: Do not be among those who shake hands [(to pledge themselves)], who stand security for loans.
text.21_Chapter, 26_Verse: If you have not what to pay, why should he [(the creditor)] take your bedding from beneath you?
text.21_Chapter, 27_Verse: Do not move back the long-standing boundary-marker, which your forefathers have established. [(Do not depart from the customs of your forefathers.)]
text.21_Chapter, 28_Verse: Have you seen a man quick in his work? He will stand before kings. He will not stand before low-life.
text.22_Chapter, 0_Verse: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, know well what is before you [(i.e., whether he is parsimonious or generous)].
text.22_Chapter, 1_Verse: And "put a knife to your cheek" if you hunger [i.e., If you see that he is niggardly, restrain yourself and do not eat with him].
text.22_Chapter, 2_Verse: Do not lust for his delicacies, for it is "deceitful" bread [i.e., not freely given.]
text.22_Chapter, 3_Verse: Do not weary yourself to grow rich [i.e., to amass "bundles" of learning]; forbear from your own understanding.
text.22_Chapter, 4_Verse: Should you blink your eyes upon it [(such "undigested" learning)], it is no longer there. For it makes wings for itself like an eagle and flies heavenwards.
text.22_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not eat bread of the miserly, and do not lust for his delicacies.
text.22_Chapter, 6_Verse: For like gall poured into his soul, so is this [(your eating of his bread)]. "Eat and drink," he will tell you, and his heart will not be with you.
text.22_Chapter, 7_Verse: The loaf that you have eaten you will vomit up [(out of shame)], and you will have wasted your words of ingratiation.
text.22_Chapter, 8_Verse: Speak not in the ears of a fool, for he will shame the wisdom of your words.
text.22_Chapter, 9_Verse: Do not move back the long-standing boundary marker, and do not enter the orphans' fields [i.e., do not take their allotted portion of the grain].
text.22_Chapter, 10_Verse: For their Redeemer is strong, and He will quarrel their quarrel with you.
text.22_Chapter, 11_Verse: Render up your heart for chastisement, and your ears for words of wisdom.
text.22_Chapter, 12_Verse: Do not withhold chastisement from the youth. If you strike him with the rod, he will not die.
text.22_Chapter, 13_Verse: You will strike him with the rod, and you will rescue his soul from Sheol.
text.22_Chapter, 14_Verse: My son, when your heart becomes wise, then my heart, too, will rejoice.
text.22_Chapter, 15_Verse: And my reins will rejoice when your lips speak righteous words [(in consequence of your heart's growing wise)].
text.22_Chapter, 16_Verse: Let your heart not envy [the prosperity of] sinners [and incline you to emulate their ways], but [preoccupy yourself] with fear of the L-rd all the day.
text.22_Chapter, 17_Verse: For thereby it shall endure and your hope will not be cut off.
text.22_Chapter, 18_Verse: Hear, my son, and you will grow wise, and [then] you may walk in the way of your heart [without injury].
text.22_Chapter, 19_Verse: Do not be among the guzzlers of wine, among the gorgers of meat for themselves.
text.22_Chapter, 20_Verse: For the guzzler and the gorger will be poor, and slumber will clothe [you] in tatters.
text.22_Chapter, 21_Verse: Give ear to your father, who begot you, and do not scorn your mother's [words], though she be old.
text.22_Chapter, 22_Verse: Purchase truth [if you must pay for it], but [even if you have paid for it] do not sell it, [(but teach it gratis)] — wisdom, reproof, and understanding.
text.22_Chapter, 23_Verse: The father of the righteous one will rejoice. He who engenders wisdom [in the heart of another] will rejoice in him.
text.22_Chapter, 24_Verse: Your father and mother will rejoice, and he who engenders [wisdom in your heart] will rejoice.
text.22_Chapter, 25_Verse: Give, my son, your heart to me, and your eyes will heed my paths.
text.22_Chapter, 26_Verse: For the harlot is a deep pit, and the strange woman is a strait well.
text.22_Chapter, 27_Verse: She, too, lurks [to snatch] suddenly and multiplies traitors among men [i.e., heretics among Israel].
text.22_Chapter, 28_Verse: Who cries "Oh!" Who cries "Woe!" One who is embattled [with men], one who talks [too much]. Who is wounded for naught? Whose eyes are bloodshot?
text.22_Chapter, 29_Verse: Those who sit late over wine, those who make inquiries over [choice] blends.
text.22_Chapter, 30_Verse: Do not look at the redness of wine; for to him who fixes his eye on the goblet, all paths are just [i.e., all transgressions seem "straight" to him].
text.22_Chapter, 31_Verse: His end is as that [of him] bitten by a snake, stung by a serpent.
text.22_Chapter, 32_Verse: [(If you become drunk)] your eyes will ogle strange women [i.e., harlots], and your heart will speak contraries.
text.22_Chapter, 33_Verse: And you will be [unhinged] like one lying in the heart of the sea, like one lying on the top of the mast.
text.22_Chapter, 34_Verse: [(When you start coming out of your stupor you will say:) "They smote me, but I did not sicken; they beat me, but I did not know it. When I wake up, I will ask for more and more."
text.23_Chapter, 0_Verse: Do not envy men of evil and do not desire to be with them.
text.23_Chapter, 1_Verse: For their hearts contemplate spoil and their lips speak deceit.
text.23_Chapter, 2_Verse: Let a house be built for wisdom's sake and let it be established for the sake of understanding.
text.23_Chapter, 3_Verse: And for the sake of knowledge let its chambers be filled with all dear and stately treasures.
text.23_Chapter, 4_Verse: The wise man is [always] steadfast and the man of knowledge increases strength.
text.23_Chapter, 5_Verse: For through [wisdom's] stratagems, you can wage war [against the evil inclination], and there is salvation in the increase of counsel.
text.23_Chapter, 6_Verse: Like a precious [(unattainable)] stone is wisdom to the fool, [and, therefore,] he will not open his mouth in the gate [of Torah. But the wise man learns a little each day].
text.23_Chapter, 7_Verse: One who thinks to do evil will be called a plotter of wrong.
text.23_Chapter, 8_Verse: Plotting wrong is sin and levity abominates a man [(to the L-rd and to his fellow men)].
text.23_Chapter, 9_Verse: If you have weakened [in helping your friend] in a day of affliction, your power [(to help yourself at such a time)] will be straitened.
text.23_Chapter, 10_Verse: [If you have weakened] from helping those who have been consigned to death, and if you desist from [helping] those who are inclined towards destruction.
text.23_Chapter, 11_Verse: Lest you say: "We did not know this" — does He who resides in the midst of hearts not understand? and does the Protector of your soul not know? And He recompenses a man according to his deeds.
text.23_Chapter, 12_Verse: Just as honey [-food] is good, my son, and just as [you put] drippings of sweet things to your palate,
text.23_Chapter, 13_Verse: So, know wisdom for your soul. If you have found it, it has a [goodly] consummation, and your hope [of reward] will not be cut off.
text.23_Chapter, 14_Verse: Do not lurk, you evildoer, near the habitation of the righteous one [(hoping to secure it when he falls upon hard times)]. Do not steal the place where he reclines.
text.23_Chapter, 15_Verse: For [though] the righteous one fall seven times, he will rise [again], and the wicked will stumble [(not to rise again)] when evil [comes upon them].
text.23_Chapter, 16_Verse: When your foe falls, do not rejoice, and when he stumbles, let your heart not be merry.
text.23_Chapter, 17_Verse: Lest the L-rd see, and it be evil in His eyes, and He turn His wrath from him [onto you].
text.23_Chapter, 18_Verse: Do not emulate evildoers; do not envy the wicked.
text.23_Chapter, 19_Verse: For there will be no endurance to evil; the light of the wicked will be extinguished.
text.23_Chapter, 20_Verse: Fear the L-rd, my son, and the king [— so long as the second does not detract from the first]. Do not mingle with variegators [(those who posit a variety of deities)].
text.23_Chapter, 21_Verse: For their destruction will suddenly arise, and who knows [the extent of] the breaking of both [the idols and the idolators]?
text.23_Chapter, 22_Verse: These things, too, [(which follow)] are intended for the wise [that sit in judgment], that they not show favoritism in judgment, [for] it is not good [to do so].
text.23_Chapter, 23_Verse: He who says to the wicked one: "You are righteous" will be cursed by the peoples, will be anathematized by the nations.
text.23_Chapter, 24_Verse: But for the reprovers it will be accounted pleasant [(to say: "You are essentially good, but …")], and a goodly blessing will come upon them.
text.23_Chapter, 25_Verse: [All] lips should kiss one who returns right answers.
text.23_Chapter, 26_Verse: Prepare your work outside [(Acquire fields and vineyards)], and put livestock in your field, and then, build your house [i.e., take a wife].
text.23_Chapter, 27_Verse: Do not offer vain testimony for your friend, that you [not] be enticed [for him] by your lips.
text.23_Chapter, 28_Verse: Do not say: "As he has done for me, so will I do for him — I will reward a man according to his acts."
text.23_Chapter, 29_Verse: I passed by the field of a lazy man [(one who does not review his learning)], and by the vineyard of a man lacking a heart.
text.23_Chapter, 30_Verse: And, behold, it was all grown over with thorns; nettles had covered its face, and its stone wall was broken down. [(If one does not review his learning, first he forgets the broad outlines, then he confuses the statements of the sages, interchanging "clean" with "unclean," and vice versa, and, ultimately, "destroying the world.")]
text.23_Chapter, 31_Verse: And when I saw this, I set my heart [to understand it]; and when I saw, I took instruction:
text.23_Chapter, 32_Verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to recline,
text.23_Chapter, 33_Verse: Then your impoverishments will come as a runner, and your wants, as an armed man.
text.24_Chapter, 0_Verse: These, too, are the analogues of King Solomon, which were set down by the men of Chizkiyah, king of Judah [when he was crowned as king].
text.24_Chapter, 1_Verse: The honor of G-d is concealing a thing [(i.e., not to make inquiries into recondite matters such as the Divine Chariot, the creation, and the statutes of the Torah)]; but the honor of kings [i.e., the sages] is searching out a thing [(trying to understand the reasons for their "fences," their decrees, etc.)].
text.24_Chapter, 2_Verse: The heavens for height, the earth for depth, and the heart of kings [(the sages)] for fathomlessness.
text.24_Chapter, 3_Verse: Remove the dross from the silver, and [only then] send the vessel to the refiner.
text.24_Chapter, 4_Verse: Remove the wicked one from before the King, and [only then] will His throne be established in righteousness. [(The community is not absolved of responsibility until the evildoers are removed from its midst and punished.)]
text.24_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not plume yourself in the presence of the king, and do not stand in the place of the great [(but keep a respectful distance)].
text.24_Chapter, 6_Verse: For it is better that it be said to you: "Come up here" than that you be made to go down before the prince, as, [indeed,] your eyes have seen.
text.24_Chapter, 7_Verse: Do not be quick to stir up strife, lest [you do not know] what to do in the end when your friend shames you [(by proving himself guiltless)].
text.24_Chapter, 8_Verse: Prosecute your quarrel with your friend [(if you must)], but do not reveal the secret of another [i.e., do not bring up to him the wrongdoing of his ancestors so that others come to know of it)].
text.24_Chapter, 9_Verse: Lest the hearer shame you [(by calling you a slanderer)] and you be unable to retract your slander.
text.24_Chapter, 10_Verse: Like golden apples [carved] into silver [-plated] vessels are words cogently spoken.
text.24_Chapter, 11_Verse: Like a golden ring among jewelry of finest gold is the reproof of a sage upon a hearing ear.
text.24_Chapter, 12_Verse: Like the cold of [(a day of)] snow on a harvest day is a faithful emissary to his sender; he revives his master's soul.
text.24_Chapter, 13_Verse: Like clouds and wind without [the expected] rain, so is one who vaunts himself over a false gift [i.e., a gift that he never gives].
text.24_Chapter, 14_Verse: So long as He withholds His wrath the Ruler may be mollified [(by penitence and prayer)], and a soft tongue [(in prayer and supplication)] may break the bone [i.e., the severity of the decree].
text.24_Chapter, 15_Verse: If you find honey, eat [only] what you need, lest you are surfeited and vomit it up.
text.24_Chapter, 16_Verse: [Similarly,] let your feet not frequent the house of your friend, lest he be surfeited with you and hate you.
text.24_Chapter, 17_Verse: A maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow is one who testifies falsely against his friend.
text.24_Chapter, 18_Verse: Like a broken tooth and a slipping foot is a trust [(in a friend)] that deceives in a day of trouble.
text.24_Chapter, 19_Verse: A worn-out garment on a cold day is like vinegar on nitre [(the vinegar eroding the nitre)], and, [similar to both,] is one who sings upon a bad heart [i.e., one who teaches Torah to a wicked disciple, who has no intention of abiding by his learning.]
text.24_Chapter, 20_Verse: If your foe be hungry, feed him bread; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink.
text.24_Chapter, 21_Verse: For [in doing so] you draw coals [from the fire to heap] upon his head, and the L-rd will reconcile [him] to you.
text.24_Chapter, 22_Verse: A north wind brews a rain, and a secret [i.e., slanderous] tongue, a scornful Countenance.
text.24_Chapter, 23_Verse: Better [for the Shechinah] to dwell on a rooftop corner than [to have] a "contentious wife" [i.e., a sinning congregation] and a house [(a Temple)] of conjunction [i.e., where idolatry is conjoined to His worship].
text.24_Chapter, 24_Verse: Cold water on a weary soul and a good report from a distant land [(on a weary soul) are both restorative to it].
text.24_Chapter, 25_Verse: [(As loathsome as)] a trodden spring and a fouled [water] source is a righteous man who bows before an evildoer [(fearing to reprove him)].
text.24_Chapter, 26_Verse: Eating too much honey is not good [(It is not good to probe recondite matters (like the Divine Chariot and the creation) before the uninitiated, for they are likely to ridicule what is beyond them)], but the probing of their [the sages'] honor [(their enactments and decrees)] is honor [to them].
text.24_Chapter, 27_Verse: A breached city without a wall is the man with no constraint to his spirit.
text.25_Chapter, 0_Verse: As snow in the summer, and as rain in harvest time, so is honor unbefitting the fool.
text.25_Chapter, 1_Verse: Like a wandering sparrow and a flying swallow [(which return to their nest], so a vain curse returns to him [(who utters it)].
text.25_Chapter, 2_Verse: A whip [is readied] for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the back of fools.
text.25_Chapter, 3_Verse: Answer not a fool according to his folly [i.e., cantankerously], lest you, too, be likened to him.
text.25_Chapter, 4_Verse: Answer a fool according to his folly [i.e., if he entices you to idolatry], lest [(if you do not answer him)] he be wise in his eyes [(assuming that you have no answer)].
text.25_Chapter, 5_Verse: He wears out the feet [of many messengers (whom he must send to amend the mistakes of the first)] and he drinks rancor [(the wrath of the object of his embassy)] — one who sends things with a fool.
text.25_Chapter, 6_Verse: "The thighs [(of other men)] are 'raised' to the lame" — [this is] a parable in the mouth of fools [(who use it as an excuse not to acquire wisdom, claiming it to be "higher" than they are.)]
text.25_Chapter, 7_Verse: Like binding a stone in a sling is giving honor to a fool [i.e., both are destined to be cast away].
text.25_Chapter, 8_Verse: Like a thorn in the hand of a drunkard [(which is destined to prick him)], so is [the following] parable in the mouth of fools:
text.25_Chapter, 9_Verse: "The Master created all, and [for His work] He hires [also] the fool and He hires 'wayfarers'" [i.e., idlers — and He feeds them all. Why work then!]
text.25_Chapter, 10_Verse: As a dog returns [to eat] what he has vomited, a fool repeats his foolishness.
text.25_Chapter, 11_Verse: Have you seen a man who is wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for one who is a fool [in his own eyes] than for him.
text.25_Chapter, 12_Verse: The lazy one says: "There is a lion on the path, a lion between the streets."
text.25_Chapter, 13_Verse: The door turns on its hinges, and the lazy one on his bed.
text.25_Chapter, 14_Verse: The lazy man hides his hand in the [hot] kettle [(to warm it)] — he is too weary to return it to his mouth!
text.25_Chapter, 15_Verse: The lazy one is wiser in his own eyes than seven wise answerers.
text.25_Chapter, 16_Verse: As one who seizes a dog's ears is he who grows wrathful over a dispute that is not his [(i.e., he will be "bitten")].
text.25_Chapter, 17_Verse: As one who tires of throwing fire-brands [throws] arrows and death,
text.25_Chapter, 18_Verse: (So) is one who deceives his neighbor [(enticing him from the paths of life to the paths of death)], and who says [(when the other becomes aware of the deception)], "I was only joking."
text.25_Chapter, 19_Verse: Without wood the fire goes out, and without the spouter [of slander] the strife is silenced.
text.25_Chapter, 20_Verse: As charcoal to [ignite] coal and wood to [fuel] a fire, so, the contentious man to stirring up strife.
text.25_Chapter, 21_Verse: The words of the spouter [of slander] are like blows and they enter one's innards [(causing dropsy)].
text.25_Chapter, 22_Verse: Like silver dross plating earthenware are lips running [(to entice men with all kinds of blandishments)] and a bad heart [beneath].
text.25_Chapter, 23_Verse: With his lips the foe will seem "estranged" [(from hatred)], but within him he will plot guile.
text.25_Chapter, 24_Verse: Though his voice be ingratiating, do not trust to it, for there are seven abominations in his heart.
text.25_Chapter, 25_Verse: Though [a deed] that is hateful [to the L-rd] be covered in darkness, his [(the perpetrator's)] evil will be revealed among the multitude.
text.25_Chapter, 26_Verse: He who digs a pit will fall in it, and he who rolls a stone [against others] will have it turn back on him.
text.25_Chapter, 27_Verse: [One who accepts] false speech [i.e., slander] hates his subjects [(Saul accepted slander against David and killed out Nov [his subjects, who assisted David])]; and the smooth [-talking] mouth causes rejection [by the L-rd of the victims of its enticements].
text.26_Chapter, 0_Verse: Do not vaunt yourself with tomorrow's day, for you know not what [evil this] day may bring.
text.26_Chapter, 1_Verse: Let another praise you, and not your [own] mouth; a stranger, and not your [own] lips.
text.26_Chapter, 2_Verse: The weight of stone and the mass of sand — the anger of a fool [i.e., the L-rd's anger against the world caused by the fool] is greater than both.
text.26_Chapter, 3_Verse: Anger is cruel and wrath torrential, but who can withstand the rancor [of the L-rd]?
text.26_Chapter, 5_Verse: Faithful are the wounds of a lover, but cloying are the kisses of a foe.
text.26_Chapter, 6_Verse: The sated soul will tread down a honeycomb, but to the hungry soul all bitter is sweet.
text.26_Chapter, 7_Verse: As a bird wandering from its nest is a man wandering from his place [i.e., a Torah scholar who does not review his learning].
text.26_Chapter, 8_Verse: [The fragrances of] oil [(balsamum)] and incense rejoice the heart, and the sweet [discourse] of one's friend [avails him] more than his own counsel.
text.26_Chapter, 9_Verse: Do not forsake your Friend and the Friend of your father, and do not come [(for aid)] to the house of your brother [Esav and Yishmael] on the day of your misfortune. Better that there dwell [in your midst] the Near One [(He who is near to those who are near to Him)] than a distant brother [i.e., the brother who distanced himself from you (viz. Genesis 27:41)].
text.26_Chapter, 10_Verse: Grow wise, my son, and rejoice my heart, and I will answer my shamer in kind.
text.26_Chapter, 11_Verse: The wise man sees the [oncoming] evil and hides [from it (i.e., he desists from sinning)], and the fools pass on [i.e., continue in their evil ways] [and] are punished.
text.26_Chapter, 12_Verse: Take [(without compunction)] the garment of him who goes security for a stranger, and take his security for an alien woman.
text.26_Chapter, 13_Verse: [If] one blesses his friend [(for his generosity)] in a loud voice early in the morning, it may become a curse to him [(i.e., he may be beleaguered for his bounty)].
text.26_Chapter, 14_Verse: A harrowing drip on a rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
text.26_Chapter, 15_Verse: He who would guard her [(from her harlotry)] might [(just as well)] guard the wind; and he will call [leprosy to come upon him (so that he can divorce her) just as a leper is cleansed by] the oil [placed upon] his right [thumb].
text.26_Chapter, 16_Verse: As iron sharpens iron, so does one man [(a Torah scholar)] sharpen his friend [(in halachah)].
text.26_Chapter, 17_Verse: He who guards the fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who guards his master will be honored.
text.26_Chapter, 18_Verse: As [with] water: the face [that you "show" it] is the face [it shows you]; so the heart of a man [i.e., the love he shows his friend] is the [(heart of the)] man [that he gets in return].
text.26_Chapter, 19_Verse: Sheol and Gehinnom are not sated [(with receiving the wicked)] just as a 'wicked' man's eyes are not sated [(with straying after his evil inclination and filling his lust)].
text.26_Chapter, 20_Verse: The refining pot for [assaying and refining] silver, and the crucible for gold, and a man [is assessed] by his praise [(i.e., by praise of his good deeds by his fellow men)].
text.26_Chapter, 21_Verse: If you crush the fool in a mortar, among the crushed grain, with a pestle, you will not remove his foolishness from him.
text.26_Chapter, 22_Verse: Know [the needs of] your sheep; give heart to your flocks.
text.26_Chapter, 23_Verse: For wealth [i.e., gold and silver] does not last forever; nor is it a crown [that is passed on] from one generation to another [(therefore, pay heed, too, to your lesser possessions.)]
text.26_Chapter, 24_Verse: [When, in the days of Nissan,] the grass appears and the verdure is seen and the mountain grass is gathered [for the flocks],
text.26_Chapter, 25_Verse: [then is the time to shear] the lambs for your clothing; and [let] the he-goats [be as] the worth of a field [to you (for you can eat the flesh and sell the hides)].
text.26_Chapter, 26_Verse: And [for your] sufficiency — for your bread and the bread of your household and (for) the livelihood of your maidens — [let] the milk of your goats [suffice].
text.27_Chapter, 0_Verse: [When their time comes,] the wicked will flee [and fall] though none pursue, and the righteous [(their heart staunch in the L-rd)] will trust [in Him] as a young lion [(trusts in its strength)].
text.27_Chapter, 1_Verse: It is trouble for the land if their officers are many, and through an understanding, knowing, man it [(the trouble)] is kept off.
text.27_Chapter, 2_Verse: A poor man [i.e., an ignorant judge] who robs the poor [(by his haste in judgment] is [like] a torrential rain [(which sweeps the field)] and leaves no bread [i.e., no produce].
text.27_Chapter, 3_Verse: The forsakers of Torah praise the wicked, but the keepers of Torah contend with them.
text.27_Chapter, 4_Verse: Men of evil will not take to heart the retribution [in store for them (and repent of their wickedness)], but the seekers of the L-rd will take all [(good and evil)] to heart.
text.27_Chapter, 5_Verse: Better a poor man [(even one who is poor in Torah)] who walks in his innocence [(doing good)] than a devious one who is rich.
text.27_Chapter, 6_Verse: The keeper of Torah is an understanding son, but the companion of gluttons shames his father.
text.27_Chapter, 7_Verse: He who increases his wealth through graft and interest gathers it for the patron of the poor. [(His swindling comes to the attention of the authorities and they confiscate his property and devote it to public improvements.)]
text.27_Chapter, 8_Verse: One who turns aside his ear from hearing [the] Torah [of another], his prayer, likewise, will be accounted an abomination.
text.27_Chapter, 9_Verse: Those who lead the just astray in an evil way will fall in their own pit, but the innocent will inherit [i.e., benefit from] the good [that they bequeath].
text.27_Chapter, 10_Verse: The rich man [i.e., the master] is wise in his eyes, but the poor man [(the disciple)] will question him [(and make him wiser)].
text.27_Chapter, 11_Verse: In the exultation of the righteous there is much glory, but in the rise of the wicked, men are searched out [and libeled].
text.27_Chapter, 12_Verse: The concealer of his sins will not succeed, but he who acknowledges and forsakes them will be granted mercy.
text.27_Chapter, 13_Verse: Fortunate is the man who fears [punishment for sin] always, but he who hardens his heart [against such fear] will fall into the evil.
text.27_Chapter, 14_Verse: A roaring lion and a growling bear is a wicked lord to a poor people.
text.27_Chapter, 15_Verse: A prince lacking understanding will increase plunder, for [he does not understand that] the hater of plunder prolongs [his] days.
text.27_Chapter, 16_Verse: The man who is guilty of another's blood [i.e., one who causes him to sin and is responsible for the loss of his soul], will run [(to seek forgiveness)] to the pit [i.e., until the day of his death]; he will not be abetted [by Heaven to repent ("so that he not be in Gan Eden and his disciple in Gehinnom")].
text.27_Chapter, 17_Verse: The walker in innocence will be saved [(from all the dangers confronting him)], but he who is devious in his ways will fall [even] in one [(and not rise again)].
text.27_Chapter, 18_Verse: The worker of his field will be sated with bread, but the runner after vanities will be sated with poverty.
text.27_Chapter, 19_Verse: The man of faith [(one who separates his tithes in faith, no one but G-d seeing him do so) will receive] an abundance of blessings, but one who is overhasty to get rich [(at the expense of the poor)] will not be absolved.
text.27_Chapter, 20_Verse: [For a judge] to show favoritism is not good. Would a man [(a judge)] incriminate himself for a loaf of bread!
text.27_Chapter, 21_Verse: Greedy for wealth is the narrow-eyed man [(he who withholds his tithes)], not knowing that want [(blight)] will befall him [for his greed].
text.27_Chapter, 22_Verse: One who reproves a man [for his sins] after Me [i.e., to follow Me] will find more favor than the "smoother of the tongue."
text.27_Chapter, 23_Verse: He who steals from his Father and his mother [(the congregation of Israel) by causing Israel to sin (thereby "stealing" His children from Him and good from them)] is a companion to the destroyer [Yeravam ben Nevat].
text.27_Chapter, 24_Verse: The "broadener" of his soul [(to attain all of his lusts)] stirs up [against himself] the attribute of justice, and he who trusts to the L-rd will be "fattened."
text.27_Chapter, 25_Verse: He who trusts to [(the machinations of)] his heart is a fool, but the walker in [the way of] the wise [(trusting in the L-rd)] will escape [(all evil)].
text.27_Chapter, 26_Verse: He who gives [charity] to the poor man [will suffer] no want, but he who averts his eyes [from him will suffer] much blight.
text.27_Chapter, 27_Verse: When the wicked rise, men hide; but when they go lost, the righteous increase.
text.28_Chapter, 0_Verse: The man [(who is in need)] of rebuke, and stiffens his neck [(not to hear it)] will be suddenly broken with none to heal [him].
text.28_Chapter, 1_Verse: In the increase of the righteous, the people will rejoice, but in the rule of the wicked, the people will sigh.
text.28_Chapter, 2_Verse: The man who loves wisdom makes his father rejoice, but the consort of harlots loses a fortune.
text.28_Chapter, 3_Verse: The king establishes the land through justice, but a man [i.e., a judge] of vanity [(who is precipitate in judgment)] destroys it.
text.28_Chapter, 4_Verse: The man who "smooth-talks" his friend spreads the net for his [own] feet.
text.28_Chapter, 5_Verse: The offense of the wicked one [sets] a snare [for his feet], but the righteous one [(not having walked in his ways)] sings and rejoices.
text.28_Chapter, 6_Verse: The righteous one knows the suffering of the poor [and tries to alleviate it]; the wicked one does not give heart to know.
text.28_Chapter, 7_Verse: Men of mockery will enflame the city, but the wise will turn back wrath.
text.28_Chapter, 8_Verse: [When] a wise man contends with a fool, whether he [(the wise man)] is angry [with him] or smiles [at him], he will find no peace.
text.28_Chapter, 9_Verse: Men of blood hate the innocent one, but the upright seek his soul [i.e., love him].
text.28_Chapter, 10_Verse: The fool vents all his wrath, and the wise man thereafter assuages it.
text.28_Chapter, 11_Verse: The ruler who gives ear to a falsehood — all of his servants are wicked.
text.28_Chapter, 12_Verse: A poor man [i.e., one who is "poor" in Torah] and a man of depth [in Torah] have met [i.e., they are on a par]. The L-rd enlightens the eyes of both.
text.28_Chapter, 13_Verse: The king who judges the poor in truth — his seat will be established forever.
text.28_Chapter, 14_Verse: The rod and rebuke give wisdom, but the youth who is given free rein shames his mother [viz., Yishmael, who ultimately caused his mother, Hagar, to be cast out.]
text.28_Chapter, 15_Verse: In the increase of the wicked, offense increases, and the righteous will look on at their downfall.
text.28_Chapter, 16_Verse: Chastise your son and he will give you peace, and he will give pleasures to your soul.
text.28_Chapter, 17_Verse: When there is no prophecy [i.e., when prophecy is removed from Israel because of their shaming the prophets], the people are breached [i.e., they become corrupt], and fortunate is the keeper of Torah.
text.28_Chapter, 18_Verse: With words [alone] the servant [i.e., one who rebels against the judges] will not be chastised, for he will perceive that there is no response [i.e., that his reprover remains silent after reproving him (so that words must be "reinforced" by blows)].
text.28_Chapter, 19_Verse: Have you seen a man hasty with his words [i.e., overhasty to respond]? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
text.28_Chapter, 20_Verse: [If] one indulges his servant [i.e., his evil inclination] from youth, in the end it will be his master.
text.28_Chapter, 21_Verse: The man of wrath will stir up the attribute of justice, and the angry man offends greatly.
text.28_Chapter, 22_Verse: The pride of man will bring him low, and the humble of spirit will court honor.
text.28_Chapter, 23_Verse: He who divides with a thief hates his [own] soul; he will hear the adjuration [(in court) to reveal the thief, but (being his "partner,")] he will not speak out.
text.28_Chapter, 24_Verse: The snare [of sin] will affright a man, but the truster in the L-rd will be emboldened.
text.28_Chapter, 25_Verse: Many seek [(to have their case adjudicated)] before the ruler, but a man's judgment is from the L-rd.
text.28_Chapter, 26_Verse: The abomination of the righteous is a man of wrong, and the abomination of the wicked is he who is just in his ways.
text.29_Chapter, 0_Verse: These are the words [of Solomon] who collected understanding [and] "vomited" [it]. This prophecy was stated by the man [(Solomon)] about himself]: Because [I said (contrary to the exhortations of the Torah)]: "Because G-d is with me — Because G-d is with me, I can" [(take many wives and multiply gold and horses and not go astray)] —
text.29_Chapter, 1_Verse: [Now I see] that I am void of [the intellect of] man and do not have man's understanding.
text.29_Chapter, 2_Verse: And I did not learn wisdom, and I [did not] know the knowledge of the holy ones [(having detracted from or added to the words of Moses)].
text.29_Chapter, 3_Verse: Who [like Moses] ascended to heaven and descended? Who [like Moses] gathered wind [(the furnace-soot) viz. Exodus 9:8-10] in his hand? Who tied the waters in a cloak? [viz. Exodus 15:8]. Who raised [the mishkan, whereby there were founded] all the ends of the earth? [If you would contend that there was someone like Moses,] what is his name what is his son's name? [(How, then, did you not fear to transgress his words?)]
text.29_Chapter, 4_Verse: All the words of the L-rd are refined [(He wrote nothing to no end and I should have heeded them)]; He is a shield to those who trust in Him.
text.29_Chapter, 5_Verse: Do not add to His words, lest He prove to you [(that you have sinned through your addition)] and you be foiled.
text.29_Chapter, 6_Verse: I ask two things of You; do not withhold [them] from me before I die.
text.29_Chapter, 7_Verse: Keep vanity and falseness far from me. Give me neither poverty nor wealth, but allot me my daily bread.
text.29_Chapter, 8_Verse: Lest [(being rich)] I be sated and [(out of pride)] deny [the L-rd], saying: "Who is the L-rd?" and lest I become impoverished and steal and take the name of my G-d [in vain, in swearing that I have not stolen].
text.29_Chapter, 9_Verse: Do not libel a servant [i.e., do not bring judgment against him] to his Master, lest he curse you and you be incriminated.
text.29_Chapter, 10_Verse: [Do not libel even] a generation that curses its father and does not bless [(but curses)] its mother.
text.29_Chapter, 11_Verse: [Even] a generation that holds itself pure in its own eyes, and does not cleanse itself of its dung.
text.29_Chapter, 12_Verse: [Even] a generation of how-haughty-are-its-eyes and how upraised its pupils.
text.29_Chapter, 13_Verse: [Even] a generation whose [outer] teeth are swords and its inner teeth knives to consume the poor from the land and the needy from [the community of] men.
text.29_Chapter, 14_Verse: The leech [i.e., the grave] has two daughters [Paradise and Gehinnom, each saying]: "Give me, give me." There are three that are never sated, and a fourth that never says "Enough!"
text.29_Chapter, 15_Verse: Sheol [the grave], the closing up of the womb [i.e., intercourse], the land unsated with water, and the fire [of Gehinnom], which never says "Enough!"
text.29_Chapter, 16_Verse: The eye that mocks a father and spurns a mother's lore will be gouged out by the ravens of the stream [(but not eaten by them, ravens being cruel to their offspring)] and will be eaten by the sons of the eagle [(eagles being merciful to their offspring)].
text.29_Chapter, 17_Verse: There are three [whose ways (i.e., destinations) are] hidden from me, and a fourth that I do not know:
text.29_Chapter, 18_Verse: The way of an eagle in the heavens, the way of a snake upon a stone, the way of a boat in the heart of the sea, and the way of a man with a maid.
text.29_Chapter, 19_Verse: Such is the way of an adulterous woman: She "eats" and wipes her "mouth" and says: I have done no wrong.
text.29_Chapter, 20_Verse: Because of three [things] the earth trembles, and because of a fourth she cannot bear [(i.e., she cannot stand up under her trembling)].
text.29_Chapter, 21_Verse: Because of a servant that attains rulership, and a scoundrel that is sated with bread,
text.29_Chapter, 22_Verse: because of a hateful woman [(a harlot)] who weds a husband, and a maidservant who inherits [the place of] her mistress.
text.29_Chapter, 23_Verse: There are four among the small [creatures] of the earth, who have been made wise [by the Creator]:
text.29_Chapter, 24_Verse: The ants, a nation that is not strong, and who [yet] prepare their food in the summer,
text.29_Chapter, 25_Verse: [the] rabbits, a nation that is not powerful, and who [yet] make their abode in the rock;
text.29_Chapter, 26_Verse: there is no king to the locusts, and they [yet] go out in a [single] swarm;
text.29_Chapter, 27_Verse: the spider grasps [walls] with her hands, and she dwells in the palaces of the king.
text.29_Chapter, 28_Verse: There are three that step securely, and a fourth that walks in confidence:
text.29_Chapter, 29_Verse: The lion, the strongest of the beasts, who does not turn back from anything,
text.29_Chapter, 30_Verse: the thigh-belted [hound (the greyhound)], the he-goat, and the king whom none can withstand.
text.29_Chapter, 31_Verse: If you have sullied [i.e., demeaned] yourself, [you are destined] to ascend; and if you have plotted [recrimination], put your hand to your mouth [in silence].
text.29_Chapter, 32_Verse: For pressing milk produces butter, and pressing the nose produces blood, and pressing anger produces strife.
text.30_Chapter, 0_Verse: The words [dedicated] to G-d, [uttered by] the king [(Solomon)], the burden [of the reproof] wherewith his mother chastised him [for his indulgences].
text.30_Chapter, 1_Verse: What [did you do that make people call you (pejoratively)] my son [and not the son of your father (an acknowledged tzaddik)]? And what [did you do], the son of my womb? [i.e., the son whom I nurtured in my womb (with additional intercourse, so that he be "whitened and quickened")] And what [did you do], the son of my vows [(whom I vowed would be "whitened" in Torah)]?
text.30_Chapter, 2_Verse: Give not your strength to women [i.e., do not dissipate your strength.] And [conduct not] your ways [in such a manner as] to destroy [the mores] of kings.
text.30_Chapter, 3_Verse: It is not [right] for kings who [belong] to the L-rd — it is not right for [such] kings — to drink [much] wine, and for [such] princes to imbibe strong drink.
text.30_Chapter, 4_Verse: Lest he drink and forget the statute [of the Torah] and [(even worse)] change the law of all the sons of poverty [i.e., the natural law of the meanest of men].
text.30_Chapter, 5_Verse: Give strong drink to the lost [i.e., to the wicked, who are destined to go lost], and wine to the bitter of soul [(those afflicted in their poverty or in their mourning)].
text.30_Chapter, 6_Verse: [For when] he drinks, he will forget his poverty and will no more remember his travail.
text.30_Chapter, 7_Verse: Open your mouth for him who cannot speak [in his own defense], in [behalf of] the judgment of all the sons [whose help] has departed [i.e., orphans].
text.30_Chapter, 8_Verse: Open your mouth, judge righteously, and [obtain] justice for the poor and unfortunate.
text.30_Chapter, 9_Verse: Who can find the woman of valor? Far more than pearls is her worth.
text.30_Chapter, 10_Verse: The heart of her husband is secure in her, and he will not lack spoil [i.e., good].
text.30_Chapter, 11_Verse: She returns him good and not evil all the days of her life.
text.30_Chapter, 12_Verse: She seeks wool and flax and does all with willing palms.
text.30_Chapter, 13_Verse: She is like the ships of merchants; she brings her bread from afar.
text.30_Chapter, 14_Verse: And she arises when it is yet night and prepares food for her household and the allotment of her young maidens.
text.30_Chapter, 15_Verse: She thinks [to obtain] a field, and she possesses it; from the fruit [i.e., the work] of her palms, she plants a vineyard.
text.30_Chapter, 16_Verse: She girds her loins with might and strengthens her arms.
text.30_Chapter, 17_Verse: [When] she takes counsel [with herself, judging] that her commerce is gainful, her candle is not extinguished at night.
text.30_Chapter, 18_Verse: She sends her hands to the distaff and her palms hold the spindle.
text.30_Chapter, 19_Verse: Her palm is spread open to the poor man, and she stretches forth her hand to the unfortunate one.
text.30_Chapter, 20_Verse: She does not fear the snow [i.e., the cold] for [those of] her household, for all of her household is clothed in multi [-colored garments].
text.30_Chapter, 21_Verse: She has made [beautiful] spreads for herself; she has clothed herself in fine linen and purple.
text.30_Chapter, 22_Verse: Her husband is distinguished [(from his friends by his fine clothing)] in the [city] gates, sitting among the elders of the land.
text.30_Chapter, 23_Verse: She makes linens and sells them, and she gives a sash to the merchant.
text.30_Chapter, 24_Verse: Strength and glory are her vestments, and she has wrought unto [her] last day [i.e., the day of her death (that it be crowned with a good name)].
text.30_Chapter, 25_Verse: She opens her mouth in wisdom and the Torah of lovingkindness is on her tongue.
text.30_Chapter, 26_Verse: She looks to the ways of [those of] her house [(that they conduct themselves truthfully and modestly)], and she does not eat the bread of indolence.
text.30_Chapter, 27_Verse: Her children have risen and praised her; her husband, and extolled her, [saying]:
text.30_Chapter, 28_Verse: Many women have done valorously, but you have risen above all of them.
text.30_Chapter, 29_Verse: Favor is false, and beauty, vain; the G-d-fearing woman, she is to be praised.
text.30_Chapter, 30_Verse: Render her the fruit of her hands [i.e., the reward of her works], and let her deeds extol her in the [city] gates. [(Thus far, the figure [melitzah]; the analogue [mashal] is Torah)].
